reviewText: There's really not much to say here, but there's enough to bother writing a review. Ultimately, if you liked The New Order, you'll probably like this too, because it's basically the same formula, hence being a standalone expansion. If you didn't like The New Order, there's not a lot here to change your mind. If you don't know what Wolfenstein is at all (what are you, some kind of commie?), here's the scoop: You kill Nazis. reviewText: Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is an adventure FPS game, developed by MachineGames, and then published by Bethesda. This game was released in early 2015 for PC, PS4 and Xbox One. It was released as a standalone expansion pack for Wolfenstein: The New Order, which was released in 2014.\n\nYou play the role of a war veteran by the name of Blazkowicz, also known as B.J.  The game play has almost no changes from the New Order. You play through the game in the first person perspective, as you navigate through levels of Nazi bases, compounds and castles. As with The New Order, you have a health monitor, and armour monitors. You are able to increase these beyond their Maximum" capacity by going into "Overload" mode

reviewText:
Standalone expansion to my personal Game of the Year for 2014.

Split into two episodes, The Old Blood catalogs the events that took place in 1946 prior to the events of Wolfenstein: The New Order. Both episodes call back to previous Wolfenstein titles, with episode 1 being a one-man assault on Castle Wolfenstein, and episode 2 dipping back into the more occult side of the Wolfenstein series (Nazi Zombies).

It pains me to say that it ultimately feels like a bit of a step back from Wolfenstein: The New Order - sporting a less remarkable cast of heroes and villains, as well as a lack of interesting locales. Pacing at the start of the game also feels very off, putting a pretty big emphasis on stealth (far from the game's strong suit). If you can look past these points however, the game still offers tons of enjoyment in terms of Nazi-dismemberment and crazy suicidal dual-wielding gun-play.

The value proposition is also sound. My full playthrough lasted just under 6 hours (attaining about 50% of the collectables). Not bad for a £15/$20 game.

If you enjoyed The New Order, I can recommend it solely on the appeal of it's gameplay - but if you're new to Machine Game's vision of Wolfenstein, go with The New Order over The Old Blood.

reviewText:
Did you like The New Order? The Old Blood is like that if it was even more tightly paced, well-polished (seriously, this plays like a game where the developers took the lessons of the first game to heart to make a better game), and had better guns. I love these guns. They're awesome.

So far, the story isn't quite as character-driven as the first game, and there's a stealth section that gets a bit repetitive early on, but once it's over, things get awesome. The game spends more time letting you play it than the last game did, and what there is to play is fantastic. Is that a rocket pistol? Yes, yes it is.

The challenge mode is awesome.

Game's not as campy as some were expecting (campy is not a bad thing!); it's very much in line with The New Order in a good way.

So yeah, if you liked The New Order, I'm pretty sure you're going to love The Old Blood.

Glad we're finally able to actually visit Wolfenstein--was surprised we never encountered it in The New Order, but I'm okay with that. I love this game.

Unrelated: any chance Bethesda can return Wolfenstein 2009 to Steam? I don't have a complete collection, and I'd really like to.

reviewText:
If you haven't played The New Order, it would be well within your interests to do so over The Old Blood. If you have, The Old Blood can be summed up with a very large “yes, but” tag attached. Are the stealth sections serviceable? Yes, but they get tedious. Is the game good at making you hate the major antagonists? Yes, but they could have used a bit more characterization. What about liking your allies? Yes, but they're very underdeveloped, save for some letters and notes scattered about. Are the nightmare levels worth your time? Yes, but they drag on a bit too long and are devoid of entertainment after a while.

Is the game good?

Yes, but there are far more flaws than The New Order.

You can read the full review here.[www.pixeljudge.com]

reviewText:
Similar to other standalone DLC, such as Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon, The Old Blood offers the enjoyment of the original game in a smaller, cheaper, and slightly varied package. This game acts as a prequel to The New Order but it isn't necessary to play it before playing this game. The game is neatly split into 2 parts each with different locales and enemies. The second part especially changes how the game is played when more supernatural elements traditional to Wolfenstein come into play. The graphics are great to look at and the attention to detail is some of the smaller things like item placement and character attributes make the game for enjoyable to play through.

The game looks great and functions well in shooting mechanics that feel like you are causing mass destruction. The game helps this process by creating a lot of gore whenever you shoot someone with a truly destructive gun. Limbs go flying when you use shotguns and nothing is quite as satisfying as getting headshots with precision. There is also stealth elements that allow you to sneak past enemies and use silenced weapons or melee takedowns. Stealth is functional but nothing too amazing to preach about. The AI that makes the enemy soldiers tough to fight against doesn't apply in stealth and makes it a breeze to just headshot anyone even marginally in your way. Stealth is also skippable and not enforced at all, though it is encouraged at some points when you are up against supersoldiers with tons of armor. Overall I had fun with the gameplay and it is solid all around.

I was able to buy this game for $4 from Green Man Gaming and based on my playtime and experiences I definitely reccommend The Old Blood for that price. It offers some of what made The New Order so great with some slight changes at a cheaper price. Even for a DLC pack it still took me 9 hours to beat the game on the hardest difficulty(which only added around an extra hour of retrying) so overall this game is a great deal for anyone looking into getting a shooter that also includes some light stealth elements. At $20 full price it may be a tougher buy but if this game ever goes on sale it is a must buy for any lovers of shooters.

reviewText:
The Wolfenstein series has delivered some pretty impressive shooter experiences over the years, but in recent times, things haven't gone so well for the franchise, as it's swapped developers multiple times. As such, many people didn't have big expectations when Wolfenstein: The New Order arrived last year from rookie studio MachineGames and publisher Bethesda. Fortunately, the two companies managed to surpass even the wildest expectations by delivering a pretty amazing shooter experience.Instead of adding any new story chapters through DLC, MachineGames decided to bring forth a standalone expansion that acts as a sort of prologue to the events in The New Order. That new experience called Wolfenstein: The Old Blood  brings fresh adventures for protagonist BJ Blazkowicz, while offering new enemies, weapons, and more.
Wolfenstein: The New Order kicked off with a suicide mission against General Deathshead's compound, and then quickly moves forward in time, chronicling the victory of the Nazis after World War 2 and BJ Blazkowicz's crusade against them.
The Old Blood focuses on his adventures before the actual start of The New Order, as Blazkowicz went through quite a few interesting moments while trying to find the location of General Deathshead's castle. What's more, those adventures take BJ to the actual Castle Wolfenstein, while searching for information, and then to a few interesting German villages.Through the two main parts of the story campaign, which are split into eight total chapters, players can learn a bit more about BJ but also about the other leaders of the German military besides The New Order's Deathshead.There are quite a few interesting moments in terms of plot but its rapid pace makes relating to some of the other characters a bit hard to do. Even so, you're in for a good story that explores the universe even more.
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood keeps the solid shooter mechanics from The New Order, sporting an old-school, fast-paced movement system as well as responsive weapons that feel awesome to use. Some weapons make a return from The New Order, including the solid assault rifle or the quite potent pistol, but there's plenty of new gear that can be used by BJ to trim down the Nazi horde. One of the first things you get to try out is a versatile pipe that can be used as a single, long component, or be split into two and used to scale walls. This mechanic is used fairly often, and while it takes a bit of time to get used to its control system, it soon becomes second nature.
There's a powerful gun that fires explosive flares, a new bolt-action rifle, as well as a pretty powerful shotgun-like shrapnel hammer. What's more, most of the game's weapons can be dual-wielded. Towards the end of the campaign, you also get to use a very impressive sawed-off shotgun, which makes getting rid of the new enemies even more satisfying.
Speaking of opponents, while you'll mostly be mowing down regular soldiers, there are a few new types of foes, including prototype versions of the hulking cyborgs seen in The New Order as well as the special surprise from the game's end - Nazi Zombies. These undead are quite powerful, and while some will just shamble around, others will rush BJ, so make sure you have places to fall back to.
Levels are quite varied, and while some areas might feel like rehashes of previous zones, especially towards the beginning, when you're making your way through the Wolfenstein prison, you'll soon reach some impressive environments, from cable car stations to the interior of Castle Wolfenstein, or a burning, zombie-infested German villages.
While the game in general makes a pretty solid showing, there are some stages where it's unclear what exactly you have to do or where it's quite hard to sneak through without alerting guards. These moments aren't that numerous, but they do keep it from perfection.
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood looks very good and uses the solid engine from The New Order to bring detailed environments, great character models, as well as fluid animations. The Nazi Zombies in particular look quite spooky and the flames engulfing most of them are well done.
The soundtrack is quite good but doesn't stand out all that much. Even so, the voice acting makes up for this, as BJ sounds as stoic as ever, whereas the rest of the cast brings a bit more humanity. Special mention goes to some of the hilarious dialog between the Nazi guards, as well as the taunts from boss enemies like Rudi Jager.
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a great follow-up to The New Order, adding plenty of adventures for BJ, not to mention new enemies, weapons, and more.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood’s narrative beats deserve a look in their own right, but not before the glue that holds them together is given its time to shine: the shooting. First-person shooters can exhibit a narrative deeper than Mariana Trench only to struggle beneath the tide due to weak systems for putting holes into the various limbs of your enemies. What Machine Games have managed to do here though is perfectly graft the art of turning Nazi opponents into a concert of puncture wounds from The New Order with a sprinkle of fresh death-dealing actions.

Running down the corridors of Castle Wolfenstein, blowing chunks out of wall and Nazi alike is a hoot in a hand-basket. Hours upon hours could be wasted detailing exactly how the art of riddling opponents with bullet after bullet is so enjoyable in Wolfenstein: The Old Blood but doing so would rob you of experiencing it yourself. Suffice to say that every round that hits or misses feels like it is doing so fairly, never becoming a tiresome slog even as the majority of the game is spent with your finger holding down the trigger.

Or triggers if you’re a fan of dual-wielding monstrous assault rifles. If you aren’t, there are still enough weapons in The Old Blood to keep you entertained with the high caliber Bombenschuss and explosive Kampfpistole offering a more traditional shooting experience. Where proceedings slow down, however, come when you’re bereft of ranged weaponry and forced to use melee weapons and stealth to succeed. It’s not that these sections are inherently poor or anything, it is simply a little jarring to be thrust away from the fun of shooting with sneaking sections.

These silent approach areas are actually quite good fun on their own. New mechanics like the melee pipe, itself used for other actions like climbing or opening specific access ways, numerous power generators bring a fresh if unwanted aroma to events. However, while clambering up walls using an old piece of plumbing stays strong throughout the game, the intriguing arrival of super soldiers hooked up to electrical systems to keep them active becomes a fleeting memory after the initial stage. The game’s most interesting new mechanic then only returns at the very end, feeling more like a throwback to forgotten times than the intelligent use of a head-scratching foe.

As games have taught us since the beginning of time, combat should always come to an explosive crescendo in boss battles. Wolfenstein: The Old Blood however has been built otherwise. They are there, one at the game’s midpoint and one coming in for the final curtain, but their quality is far from consistent. Your first locking of horns with a boss is a difficult encounter where spacial awareness and effective movement are just as important as a good aim. The second is less so, leaving a bitter taste in the mouth with a combat situation that’s more suited to Borderlands or Diablo than the pseudo-historical Wolfenstein universe.

That’s not to say that Wolfenstein: The Old Blood fumbles massively in its closing hours. If anything, the final act feels absolutely perfect after chasing down the SS’s Paranormal Investigation team. We’re not going to spoil what actually happens here but it’s a bundle of fun wrapped up in excellent shooting mechanics. The latter chapters actually show that Machine Games aren’t afraid to focus on the fun rather than the fact. All through Wolfenstein: The Old Blood, the onus is placed on stretching a semi-psychotic grin over your face and not on creating a deep or thought provoking experience.

It’s not that this intention devalues the surrounding narrative, far from it in fact. Wolfenstein: The Old Blood’s tale grabs you by the throat and will not let go, dragging you by the neck through some joyous battles only to drop you on a somewhat unsatisfying ending after 6-8 hours. B.J. Blazkowicz has long been gaming’s most one-dimensional character after being presented to us only as a face way back at his first appearance. However in only a few hours, The Old Blood manages to help build the foundation for a character you care about more than in many other franchises.

Don’t be fooled by the outwardly short-sounding time-frame though, as it actually helps the game more than hinders it. Nothing ever hangs around long enough to feel laborious or overused. Those strong-arming stealth sections can be tiresome on their own, but you always know that just around the corner is a chaotic dance of bullet-infused excitement. Often the combat arenas that show themselves in Castle Wolfenstein can become nothing more than shooting grey shapes in a grey environment filled with grey smoke. Aesthetically pleasing grey, but grey shapes all the same.

Sadly it isn’t all singing and killing through. Great segments frequently come across as rushed while the corridors joining them together feel like the same ones you’ve walked down before. B.J. ends almost every chapter by being knocked out with falling rock ex machina, leaving you with the sour taste of a severely overused mechanic to end sections. It’s actually funny when you think about it after completing the game, just a shame that this humor doesn’t come across as you’re enduring it again and again.

The PC version of Wolfenstein: The Old Blood isn’t exactly a shining beacon for quality either. It’s entirely possible to get the game running beautifully, just at the expense of some extra work in the background. The texture streaming system used falters as often as it succeeds in presenting a good-looking game. Terrible vertical sync issues also plague the game, often leading to scurrying through information posted online about this game’s bigger brother in order to get everything working.

Sounds and conversations regularly miss the mark on even the highest specification systems out there without you having to take to fixing it yourself. Everyone should be able to enjoy Wolfenstein: The Old Blood the way it was meant to be played, rather than the need to enter the developer console or creating your own cache folder for the game. Even when the sounds all sync up properly, the weapons’ fire often feels like it’s got the resounding strength of a sneezing shrew. Odd really when the gun in your hand fires rounds bigger than most rodents.

All in all even with these issues, The Old Blood is a worthwhile and enjoyable experience. If you run through the whole game in a single 6 hour sitting, prepare to be shunted into what is at its core an Indiana Jones movie, but replacing Indy’s trademark bullwhip/fedora combo with a pair of automatic shotguns and cybernetic Rottweilers. Machine Games broke the mold when they brought Wolfenstein: The New Order into the world to be one of last year’s surprise hits, or so we thought. Wolfenstein: The Old Blood proves that a little new blood is what was needed to keep the Wolfenstein series alive for many years to come.

Pros

[+] Rip-roaring shooting
[+] Utterly gorgeous
[+] Perfectly paced for the most part

Cons

[-] Technical issues plague some locations
[-] Ends abruptly

Final Score 6.5 out of 10

reviewText:
If you enjoyed Wolfenstein: The New Order, you will definitely enjoy The Old Blood. If you never picked up The New Order, this is a cheap alternative as well as a prequel to decide if you wish to buy the main game. Keep in mind that this review might contain minor spoilers

The Old Blood is definitely worth the 20 dollars on the steam shop (depending on where you live of course, i refused to pay $40 AUD so i got it somewhere else)

This Standalone Expansion/DLC is what companies should be doing instead of this stupid 3 maps or season pass setups and I'm glad that Machine games brought this system back.

The old Blood is 8 Chapters long, shorter than the main campaign of course but for 20 dollars its definitely worth it. While you don't get all the futuristic weaponry of the new order like the assault rifle combined with rockets, there are still a variety of weapons that make the game seem a little bit fresh. A useful addition is a rusty old pipe which can be split into two parts so you can climb cracked walls and use it as a melee weapon in silent takedowns as well as a open up doors, keeping them open while slide running to get past heavy doors. Although i did prefer a knife it was a nice alternative for a melee weapon. Theres also the addition of a bolt action rifle and another huge shotgun that i suspect alot of people will come to love if they go the shoot first ask questions later play style over the stealth approach.

Your enemies of course are the Nazis, which include a vicious Dog handler who seems to spend a little to much time with them to be a people person, a stuck up commander who only cares about results and a rude, wine loving historic researcher high in the Nazi ranks, what's not to love. Oh and like RTCW you get some of the more... Non-Conventional enemies.

The perk system is a back as well although there does seem to be a perk that can quickly annoy you if you keep holding the sprint button while trying to go backwards.
There are also the usual collectibles, letters, gold and concept art as well as information on characters which when you go hunting for them will definitely give you more time to enjoy the scenery while exploring the areas of Castle Wolfenstein and the village of Wulfburg, a historic city that seems to have its own dark secrets that the Nazis wish to uncover and use for their own agenda. Your job of course is to stop them, stepping into the shoes of one William B.J." Blazkowicz

If there are people who have played The New Order you will recall a bed that would let you play the first level of Wolfenstein 3D. Well The Old Blood adds to that by adding the ENTIRE first episode in hidden locations
date:
1 for each chapter and you even get to vs. Hans Grosse! This is definitely a welcome addition although for some reason the music tracks of the games are randomized and the first levels track doesn't even seem to be there at all (it might be there but when I did every level I did not get it) and I was a little disappointed that the SS soldiers in the Wolfenstein 3D levels didn't scream Schutzstaffel! (protection squad!) and Mein Leben! (My Life!) when you killed them. Those words made them a memorable enemy for me and it was a shame I didn't get to hear them here.

There are a couple of down sides though as well as a bit of confusion. A little bit into the game there were these super soldiers connected to electric generators hooked up on pipes that would deliver electricity to their battery packs. They only appear in this one area and then disappear till the last chapter which they really could have made more use for in later chapters. The confusing bit is that of the identity of your starting companion. Wesley. Now this could be a nod to agent one from RTCW and is a different character or he somehow (and there should be no way that he did) survived his electrocution in Return to Castle Wolfenstein. I believe that this game comes after the events of RTCW or 2009 chronologically. Kind of confuses you there but you can check the timeline on the Wiki page if you wish (although no confirmation as of yet).
The ending did feel a little underwhelming but did an alright job connecting the game to the new order.

You also do need to make another choice but the only thing this seems to affect is the concept art you get in a specific chapter.

Finally there are challenges you unlock after getting to specific areas of a chapter which you can choose the difficulty for and will give medals depending on how well you did.


I personally didn't have any issues with the game crashing
recommended: locking up causing any kind of problem with my PC. The game was easy to alt-tab out and in with no lag or frame loss whatsoever and automatically paused when you did so if you did hit that combination accidently you wouldn't just die offscreen. If you are sick of all these military like shooters coming out nearly every year these days. Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a perfect choice to get off that road and try something different.\n\nI give this game a 9/10."

reviewText:
Product received for free

I don't understand why this game had originally got such lousy reviews. It is actually quite long, with many varied enviroments, and an unexpectedly involved story. It features new weapons, new gamplay elements, bosses, and enemies. It is basically like The New Order but is more over the top and funny. You can tell the devs had a good time putting all their fun ideas into this that didn't make it into the other game.

I got this game for free by pre-ordering DOOM, but now I regret not purchasing it sooner.

If you liked The New Order, you will love this.

reviewText:
I finally finished the game and enjoyed it so very much.

The old Blood is the prequel to the New Order.

I was not able to play The New Order when it came out so when the Old Blood came out I bought the package intentionally playing the prequel first.

This also means I will not be tempted to compare The Old Blood to The New Order but judge the Old Blood for the game it represents itself in isolation and not in light of another game.

The game looks beautiful and the different difficulty settings should allow a challenge for all players of all skill types.
The gameplay is linear and it is holding your hand, showing you where to go at all times. It is very hard to get completely lost.
While this might not be for everyone, the story is still amazing and with every chapter you just want to see more of what happens next.
The last chapter or two felt a little rushed to me from the story line perspective and I feel another 1 or 2 chapters could have been added to flesh out some of the characters you meet a little more.

The voice acting and atmosphere in this game is very well done and for me it was quite easy to get invested into the characters that fight on your side as well as wanting to know more about the bad guys in charge.
Helga and Rudi are one example of great characters I enjoyed reading up the lore on.
Throughout the game you find notes, diary entries or letters from main main good/bad characters or just some random soldiers/people, each containing interesting information, adding to the lore of the game, giving it more character with each note.

You are equipped with your standard silencer mounted pistol, a sweet machine gun and find a few more power guns along the way. You can dual equip your weapons for greater impact but make sure to keep an eye on your ammunition at all times.
Though ammo is plenty and as along as you use the right gun for the right job you should not have many issues.

Every chapter can be played, either head-on fire fight or stealthed through, with the exception of the mandatory shootouts off course.
Enemies are plenty and while there is not a huge amount of different enemy types, each special can be dealt easily ones you know their weakness.
Throughout the game, when completing chapters you unlock some areas of the game as Challenge Mode playable arenas.
This adds great fun and a great way to allow you to kill more bad guys on demand :)
Playing an area in Challenge mode locks you into parts of a previous played map, arena style, in which you get rewarded with points for successfully rampaging through waves of different enemies.

Overall the game was great fun to play and even though it took me, as a FPS noob, close to an hour to take down the final boss in the end it never got to frustrating to not wanting to continue.

I would certainly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys FPS games, the Wolfenstein franchise or simply enjoys shooting their way through waves of Nazi super soldiers.

If you read all this and want to know/see more you can watch my playthrough here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IFasAOzXvCE&list=PLpd5HpREizQ3y5K2Dzz94ZJgshjDpi0mK

reviewText: All in all, The Old Blood provides a meatier singleplayer experience than what is present in many full priced games these days. Long time fans of the series will appreciate the familiar setting of Castle Wolfenstein, and those who grew impatient with the story-heavy sections of The New Order will be pleased with the tighter pacing and more intense action sequences found here. Twenty dollars seems like a very fair price given the quality of the experience, and I wouldn’t hesitate to recommend this expansion to anyone who enjoyed The New Order or singleplayer shooters in general.\n\nRead Full Review [www.newgamenetwork.com]

reviewText:
Time to kill some Nazi's!  All kinds of Nazis to kill from electro mutant nazi's, old school pixel nazis, and even grammer Nazi's.  This game takes place before The New World Order so play Old Blood first since it leads right into TNO as the cool kids say.  Awesome story with great voice acting really makes the game feel alive compared to other games.  Price is right for this budget game that is 6 chapters long which can last 6-8 hours on first playthrough.

The graphics are good?  Ended that with a question mark because this game has the same fatal flaw as doom, no flashlight to see anything.  Not sure why they spent so much time upping the graphics when most of the game is dark as in cant see anything, or everything is grey, theres really no variety of color at all.  Seems the artist chose one pallet of colors and used it for the whole game which makes even great graphics very boring to look at.   There also isnt any music which is odd, makes the game really feel dead and less fun without colors and music.

There are zombies in this one, nazi zombies, but their nothing special since only a few appear on the screen at the time.  These Romero zombies go down with one shot to the head too making them even less challenging.  Has anyone seen a zombie movie?  One zombie is not to scary but tons are, and this game only has a couple on the screen at a time.  Making it easier is you are BJ Blazkowitz with grenade launchers dual machine guns, the zombies stand no chance against that arsenal so its not very fun, its just to easy.

Story is solid with 5 levels from classic wolfenstein mixed in with this game.  There is a timeline to the game or Wolf Cannon, the Helga in this game is different Helga than in RTCW.  This is not a reboot of the series its all one timeline.  While Wolfenstein's roots are in the stealth genre this game features mostly stealth except for a few sections where the player can use the classic run n gun gameplay.  The stealth sections rely on a mechanic of taking out a commander, this can become repetitive which leaves this shooter without much diverse gameplay which can bore regular gamers leaving this title mostly for long time wolfenstein fans.  Oddly the game contains throwback gameplay to Wolf3d which features more action related gameplay because stealth slows it down, a lesson from then that seems to have been lost in this entry into the Wolfenstein franchise which over relies on stealth slowing down the game.

Rating:   7/10  Value:  $14.99
*the Bundle containing TNO and Old Blood is worth the price at $45

reviewText:
It's incredible that Machinegames did this with just 1 year of development.

I played it on Uber difficulty (you should too if if you're fine at FPSs) and it took me 12 hours.

If you're versed with The New Order, all the best aspects return. The best gunplay in many years, with cool new weapons (love the Bombenschuss) and more emphasis on melee with the pipe which got just a tiny intro in The New Order. Great combat scenarios are made even better with longer battles, more enemies, complex level design, more flanking possible by them, and when the zombies come then the dynamic changes where you can pit AI vs AI while you sit back. Even on the highest difficulty, enemies never feel like bullet sponges and there's always a quick solution to every big enemy.

The introduction of the challenge mode is something I've been wanting ever since I finished The New Order, because The New Order had excellent shooting mechanics and feel. It's awesome here because you get to play around with the multiple weapons and test your might on various difficulties while comparing your scores to friends or the world on leaderboards. Only thing that would be perfection like Mirror's Edge would be able to see how other players' runs went with a direct-to-Youtube situation or ghosts.

The game is absolutely hilarious from Blazko's commentary to Nazi conversations (graveyard talk in last chapter: I liked Fritz. He made a very good strudel") to several memorable character moments ("you look like a BJ"
recommended: village drunkard). The Nazis are humanised even more here

reviewText:
If you liked The New Order then you should enjoy The Old Blood. Shoot lots of Nazis, slit the occasional throat, stab robot dogs in the neck, blow lots of things up. It's very enjoyable with great sound, music & visuals.

Some people have reported issues with the idtech 5 engine so that's something to keep in mind and the game is painfully short, only 4 or 5 hours. Also the level design can be a bit derivative, but those moments when you're inside narrow corridors with duel weapons is when the game really shines.

Worth checking out for all FPS fans, even if the price is a little steep.

reviewText: Adding another 6-8 hours of Nazi killing excitement, The Old Blood trades in character development and much of a storyline for action.  It's not a bad choice; although the development in The New Order ran surprisingly deep for an FPS, sidelining character stories in The Old Blood gives you a solid block of game play rather than cut scenes and minor fetch quests.  It's a little unfortunate that, like The New Order, this game starts with a too-long quasi-tutorial sequence that wears out its welcome before allowing you to get into the meat of the game.  Happily, once you get invested in carrying around an arsenal and filling enemies with lead, you'll largely forget the earlier tedium of avoiding and depowering Nazi mech suits but it's a stumble the franchise has made twice now and I hate having to say Just stay with it and it'll get better

reviewText:
What a Strange way to Announce Fallout 4

Do you like One-man Army Games, Do you like bloooood, do you hate Nazis
You are the same character as from the last game in this story of blood and gore. Before the war was over you were set out on a mission to try and end by killing some dude and taking his ♥♥♥♥♥. now why do i say this well first off the story is awesome and that is for you too endulge in. but get this you kill things... Nazis.  34 Gbs of nazis to be exact and is a bang for your buck at 20$.

The Pros:
- It takes place before the end of the war so its kind of nice to get both sides the before/after scenario
- You are 'murican makes all games guns galore
- Multiple paths to take on some missions gives it a nice feel in terms of options and what you are to do
- Good level design (linear) that meets all your lovely running and crouching needs
- AI isn't a total draw from the game isn't amazing but its good it isn't terrible
- Plenty of collectibles that will keep you looking
- Simple game, easy controls like the last (no change)
- The german residents actually speak german (from what i can tell)

The Cons:
- Not awhole lot of options in the menus to mess around with graphics and hud which can draw some people away with not so powerful pcs
- No upgrades a problem i had with the last a game where you feel like you are making no progression besides the story doesnt feel like a full game in my opinion but it makes up for it in the guns being scattered out somewhat throughout the game


Overall if I had to give a rating nein/zehn.

reviewText:
This is my second review, so you can tell that I don't write reviews about games too often. I couldn't help but write a review about this game. To start things off, I think this game is severly underrated. I had seen it on Steam occasionally, and I had seen it on sale, but I was never interested in it. I was in a Twitch stream about a month ago (the streamer was streaming The New Order), and I instantly fell in love with the beginning story. It gave me chill bumps, which is kinda ridiculous. I bought The Old Blood not too long ago, and I just started playing it. I can't express in words on how much I enjoyed this game. If you're looking for a fps with amazingly gameplay and story, I would definitely recommend this series.

Pros:
-Graphics
-Intense moments
-Lots of weapons
-Different types of enemies
-Emotional attachment to characters
-Amazing story line
-Humor throughout
-Great voice acting
-Broken up into chapters

Cons:
-Short story
-Not a lot of saving points

Don't just take my opinion for this-- buy it and try it out for yourself!

reviewText:
The old blood is an FPS that takes place during world war II and it's a prequel to Wolfenstein: the new order. It took me about 4 hours to complete. Although I rushed through it pretty quick and I played it on one of the easier difficult settings. There is also challenges and collectables available so you can probably get a few more hours out of it if you wish.

The first levels in the castle is quite boring and repetitive, but once you get out of there the game opens up a bit more. The story is alright. The voice acting is good and the cutscenes too. You can also listen to a lot of guards talking to get more backstory and read different letters and notes that are spread out through the levels.

A lot of weapons that are fun to use. The gunplay is okay. You earn unlocks as you play, like health and armor upgrade for example. There is about 3-4 different enemy types, but you will mostly see the standard nazi soldiers, which can get a bit repetitive too.

Wolfeinstein the old blood is an average game. The price is lower then new order though, so I expected less in terms of lenght and quality. I would recommend this game if you like FPS, history (especially world war II) or if you just want a few hours of decent gameplay. If you are on the edge, wait for a sale, then it's definitely worth your money.

reviewText:
What people don't seem to be saying, for some reason, is that this is essentially a remake of 2001's Return to Castle Wolfenstein. The castle escape, the village, Kessler, Helga, the excavation, it's all there. I, for one, love that game, so it's interesting to replay sections of it as seen through the eyes of this modern adaptation-of-sorts. I've read a few complaints that the story isn't as good as The New Order, but The Old Blood is a completely different animal. I also find it indicative of consumer ingratitude when, after being gifted a game that manages to have a rare balance of great gameplay, action, and story, critics immediately get their claws out when the expansion doesn't have exactly that balance regurgitated again. That's not to say the game fails in it's story, but that I believe the intention behind it was different - The Old Blood is clearly self-aware of the genre it's throwing back to. How can B.J's grim musings and the emotional connection that the first game gave us fit into a game in which a character comments that B.J is wearing no clothes, and then seconds later we are made to watch B.J remove half a dozen weapons off his person one-by-one? This moment is the most tongue-in-cheek moment in the game, and the most telling as to what the intention behind it was. If you want a dark narrative that muses on the brutality and futility of war, look elsewhere.

It's a shorter game than The New Order, and gameplay-wise it's a return to a much more traditional action-oriented format; you'll be thrust into large rooms or open spaces with no exit until you eliminate all the bad guys that come pouring out, and the gameplay favours player-mobility as well as a quick trigger-finger. There's also many secret areas, including playable Wolf3D levels in each level of the game.

In saying all that about the run-and-gun appraoch, the wonderfully flexible combat system of The New Order returns, and realistically you could play most of the game in stealth if the desire took you. I found that the maps were built to offer a higher level of difficulty when it came to the stealth approach - the guards cross paths more frequently, making eliminating them more difficult, and there are tonnes of commanders waiting around to call an alarm should anyone spot a corpse - so I found myself having to retry different tactics multiple times to find a method that worked. I liked this, and felt that I was unravelling a puzzle every time I managed a successful stealth run.

But this game really thrives under a guns-blazing approach - there are a few new weapons, new perks, and new enemies, that all beg you to go loud and let chaos reign. Explosions rip through the air, enemy body parts disappear in a pink mist, and if you turn your sound up, the guns thump and pound in a satisfying fashion.

Whereas The New Order felt like wonderful blend of old and new, this leans more on the 'old' end, and I don't in any way mean that as a criticism. The Old Blood is a chance to get the adrenaline racing, rewarding players who like to move fast, hold their finger on the trigger and grind their enemies into powder, in other words, it plays like a classic ID game. I've read no confirmation that this was the intention of the developers, but the experience is uncanny, and if you grew up on shooters in the late 90s/early 2000s, it's a really satisfying nostalgia trip. The best part about it is that it's wrapped so competantly in a glorious HD package, that it doesn't feel like it's thrusting the nostalgia in your face, and it never feels like a one-trick-pony. It's a relatively short game, the term 'standalone' should alert you to the fact it is an expansion pack, but it's a solid game and a wonderful throwback that's worth the price, especially if you can get it on sale.

reviewText:
Finally, more Wolfenstein! Could not be happier. This game takes place before the events of 'The New Order'. A nice insight into the Nazi war machine before they became dominant and so technologically advanced. Graphically the game looks great, but only at a distance. If playing up close on PC then the image looks grainy.

The game starts off with around an hour of stealth. While doing I found plenty of health packs that were unnecessary. If the stealth had continued any longer I would have fallen asleep. Not the bombastic Wolfenstein I had come to love.
Your main weapon/item of use is the pipe. Get friendly with it as you'll be using it a lot. Really, like every 10min. You get the chance to collect gold bars but the places you find them are so random, some just out in the open! A safe, chest or behind a painting yes, in front of a door or on a bookshelf, no.
I warn you, this game is brutal on Uber difficulty, but then you would expect nothing less.

This is a great game if you want more Wolfenstein action, although the action is broken up by (in my opinion) too much stealth, breaking the flow of what should be an adrenaline fuelled romp.

7/10

reviewText:
The Old Blood is a standalone prequel to Wolfenstein The New Order. This means that you dont need to have TNO to play TOB. The game costs around 140 kr and gives you a lot of new content. I used around 5 hours to complete the game on normal without looking too much after secrets and other collectibles. It's not as long as TNO, but you get so much for the money.

TOB brings you back to WW2 where you yet again meet B.J.  This game feels very much like the TNO. The gameplay, weapons and AI feels the same, but you get a new story, new weapons, new enemies and much more lore which ties with TNO. It feels like this game is a tribute to the old RTCW. The village setting is there, the zombies are there, the supernatural is there and castle wolfenstein is there. It feels so good fight the undead again which is missed from TNO. The setting is so much scarier and spookier this time and I love it.

The story is good and the boss fights are fair enough. The gore systems is just pure awesome and keeps the good old wolfenstein mood. The graphics looks great even on my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC. I run it on medium with 50-60 fps and it looks so nice.

+ You have to buy this game if you liked TNO.
+ New content, new story +++
+ Gore :D
+ Gives you the Wolfenstein feel.
+ Challenges.
+ Secret Levels (9 retro levels with bossfight)

10/10

reviewText:
A very cool shooter for about 10 hours. Including all nightmare eastereggs (Wolf 3D levels) an some challanges. And alternative choice/achievement. I didn't get bored, what issues most people had with The New Order were fixed here.
It is basically less cinematic, more action oriented. Story is still there, but it happens as you shoot your way through it (besides, maybe the prologue).
The game has few technical problems because of it's engine, but after creating a folder that the game didn't make, everything were smooth on max settings, very well optimized, but not as pretty as some might want.
Still, loads of fun! 9/10 from me. If you are not Wolfenstein franchise fan, you might give it less, but you sure should at least try it!
In my opinion, better than the original New Order, but they should be bought and played together (in whatever order).

reviewText:
*This review was written when the game was priced at $4.99

Much has been said about how New Order is a return to old school shooter greatness or is, at the very least, ushering it in, and while I wouldn't say that it's a pretender to the throne, based on what I've played of Old Blood, this series is far closer to an interim king until the real deal comes along.

Wolfenstein has been rebooted before, surprisingly both times hitting their marks in 2001 and 2009 respectively, but never has it been done before without id's involvement. I mean sure, it uses an id engine, but the company logo is nowhere to be found on retail boxes or store descriptions. This is without question a Bethesda and Machineworks baby, but unlike when Bethesda usually slaps their less than pristine name on IP's they purchased and act like they created something, they actually earned the right to do it here.

Old Blood is a prequel to New Order, seeming to reference very little about NO as far as I've found. The story here is a basic kill dem gnatzies"

reviewText:
Wolfenstein The Old Blood is the prequel to last years The New Order. But will you want to see how things began ?

Wolfenstein The Old Blood takes place before the events of The New Order. We play as B.J Blazkowicz as we are tasked to go inside the Wolfenstein castle and retrieve a folder that holds the place where a nazi scientists holds experiments on people. But you get captured and it's up to you to escape.

Gameplay is identical to The New Order. Stealth play's a bigger role in the game than in New Order. There are more enemies you can't fight with gunfire and have to sneak past. The run and gun option is still available but it's not as fun as in The New Order. There are a few new weapons which are cool to use like the pipes, cause the executions can get pretty brutal. Overall the gameplay is identical to The New Order.

Graphics are the same as in the new order. It still looks great, the lighting effects are amazing. The environments are big and open and all look very nice. The textures aren't the best, but the game still looks very good.

The soundtrack is fantastic, it really play's well with the game. Some of the music is intense during the more intense firefights and it could get emotional during the cut scenes.

The game is pretty easy on the lower difficulties, but the higher ones will provide a bigger challenge and trust me they are very very hard. If you are not new to Wolfenstein you can try out normal, but if you want a real challenge then try out the hardest difficulty.

The game itself is pretty short, it took me 3 hours to finish the entire thing and like Wolfenstein there is a choice you can make that will change the outcome. Tons of collectibles, upgrades and secret Classic Wolfenstein levels you can find.

There isn't many bugs, the game runs very smoothly, maxed out I can get 60FPS  no problem.

Overall this is a must own to any FPS game fan or even a Wolfenstein fan. The game is not as good as The New Order, but this is still a very good game. Worth it at full price.
I give Wolfenstein: The Old Blood a 8.5/10

reviewText:
Rating - 84/100
In a sentence - As a much tighter-structured whole, this game is a must-buy for fans of The New Order, and should be on the shortlist for anyone who doesn't flat-out hate FPS games.

Much like Farcry Blood Dragon (which is also fantastic, if you haven't tried it yet), The Old Blood is a standalone expansion for its parent game. In this case, Wolfenstein: The New Order. Old Blood is a prequel story, so the 2 are only barely related, but I would still recommend playing New Order first, for a few reasons.

Taken as a whole, Old Blood is an extremely solid experience. It moves along briskly, leads you where you need to go without being intrusive about it, the action is visceral and exciting, the weapons are satisfyingly familiar and all useful, the campaign is just about the perfect length (5-6 hours, plus unlockable leaderboard challenges to repeat later), and the story is a nice blend of lighthearted nazi-killing fun and the brutal horrors of war.

The story this time around is about BJ and his team sneaking into Castle Wolfenstein in order to get the location of Deathshead's compound (where New Order took place). Naturally, things don't go quite according to plan, and you have to fight even harder to get out than you did to get in. I'm not going to spoil anything, since the experience is the most important thing, but I was pleasantly surprised. It IS a 5-hour prequel game, though, so don't expect them to throw the canon on its head.

The graphics are about what you would expect if you played New Order, in that they are extremely similar. You'll be treking through shiny, gleaming nazi castles, dank and musty sewers, destroyed towns, and ancient ruins. All of the environments looks pretty, but I was disappointed to find very few stop-and-stare-in-awe moments like I had with Rage (another idTech5 game). The texture work here is a little lacking, as well. Characters look phenomenal, but the world is somewhat lackluster when you get up close. In a game where so much time is spent hiding in small corridors/rooms fighting and hiding from nazis, you start to notice it. Once again, though, these are small problems, and were the same with New Order. If you didn't mind it there, you certainly won't mind it here.

One thing that I don't remember being a problem with New Order, though, is performance issues. I had a lot of framerate issues here at 1080P that I don't have in other, prettier games at 4k. I also had this weird recurring problem where the game would run in slow-motion, and I'm not talking about low framerate or stuttering. The framerate never once dropped below 30fps, but every once in a while the game would slooooooow down, like someone just activated Max Payne's bullet time. Weapons would fire slower, enemies (and BJ) would move slower, and the environment would react slower. Turning off Adaptive VSync helped with that, but it introduced HORRIFIC screen tearing. Absolutely awful, unacceptable, I-don't-want-to-play-any-more screen tearing. If the performance had been maybe 20% worse, it would have been a serious problem for me, but I stuck with it. For reference, I have a QX9650 and a GTX980.

The sound and music in here are well-done, too. I wish the weapon sounds had a bit more weight to them (why do id games, more often than not, have guns that sound like toys?), and some of BJ's little under-his-breath aside moments feel shoehorned in, but all in all, sound and music lived up to the challenge. The music in the Wolf3D nightmare" sequences gets tedious

reviewText:
First Impressions Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F10TVjtkIAM

Summary:
More of the same from the Wolfenstein franchise, and as an extension of The New Order, it does the job as a stand-alone DLC. Now those looking for the same storytelling from TNO, this game isn't going to bring it like it's predecessor. The writing, while still good,  isn't of the same quality. But the core gameplay is still a good mixture of run and gun action and stealth. Some of the additions that the game brings with the Challenge mode and more explosive weapons were definitely appreciated, and as a level pack overall, it's a good time. The aesthetic is there, and the feel for the overall game is pretty excellent overall. There's still a great amount of little touches that the game has, such as Doom easter eggs. When it comes down to it, if you wanted more gameplay like TNO, then The Old Blood does the job. It's not going to blow you away while doing it, but it's still worth the price of admission.



Lists:
+:
Gunplay from the series is still excellent, especially compared to other games in the FPS genre. It's more of what the TNO brought, and that's perfectly fine for me.
Good combination of fast FPS action, but adds the elements of smart tactical shooting as well. Felt like of the modern day FPS, it's one of the ones that gets the formula down to something that I enjoy.
Stealth is rewarded still, which is nice to see. Not forced in certain sections (which I enjoy), but gives you a good reason to actually go quiet.
Like the original, still love the tiered health system. A good mixture of new and old.
AI still a good challenge, even on lower difficulties.
There is still good writing here. Again, it's not the best of the genre, but there's some new characters that I did enjoy. It's more sparse.
Like the challenge system. Added some replayability to the game.
Aesthetic comes through loud and clear, and definitely has the Wolfenstein feel to it.
Good level design overall.
Like the small easter eggs that you can find in the game. I want a doom demon plushie/stress ball.
More explosive weapons this time around. Who doesn't like Explosive weapons?
Price seems appropriate for the stand-alone DLC type gameplay.
-:
Those looking for the extension of the Wolfenstein: The New Order gameplay may find that they've got a couple of surprises here. The gameplay is more straight forward, with less opportunities for stealth, and the gameplay in my opinion has become less dimensional.
It's more of the same. If you're looking for innovation, it's not here.
The narrative for the game just doesn't compare to the original. Not to say that it's bad, it's average in the FPS genre, and had some alright moments. But compared to TNO, which was one of the best in the last several years, it just doesn't compare.
The game to me had a weak opening. It was hard to get into compared to the original game.
More turret sections. Never a fan.
Target Audience:  Those looking for more gunplay/action similar to The New Order, but are not expecting innovation.

reviewText:
MachineGames is fully committing to its strategy of old-school tradition mixed with new-style enhancements. Namely, the expansion pack. Remember the expansion pack missions for games like Quake I and II and Starcraft? That is what this is. It's a 7/10 contractual obligation for fans who want more of what The New Order was.

I don't say this to slag it off. I enjoyed The Old Blood. It's a lot like The New Order, except the game is set in 1946 and we've gone back to the hoary old Wolfenstein cliches: Fighting Nazis inside a castle, ♥♥♥♥ing with the occult, robotic super soldiers, dogs, secrets, all that ♥♥♥♥. As a Wolfenstein game that plays with all that crap, it's a nice effort. Compared to say, Wolfenstein 2010 (the one published by Raven Software).

My problem with The Old Blood is that beyond improving dual assault rifles and kicking the engine up a notch (up a notch to the point where my graphics card freaks out and starts putting flicking textures everywhere so that the game resembles a VR sim going haywire), there isn't really much improved with the game. The perks are still kind of bland, and the game tries to dissuade you from stealth to GO SHOOT SOME MORE NAZIS. This game kind of throws off its storytelling to get you to SHOOT MORE NAZIS, but I found that to be okay. Shooting Nazis is cool.

There's some boneheaded plays from MachineGames here, though. The game makes another bid for old-school cred by tying nine achievements to the secret Wolfenstein 3-D levels you get to play when you find a bed and go to sleep! The problem is, Wolfenstein 3-D doesn't really hold up, and MachineGames' treatment of those levels sure ♥♥♥♥ing doesn't help! They got the levels exactly right, but there's a fundamental difference between how Wolf 3-D and The Old Blood/New Order plays, and MachineGames didn't change anything from their game for those levels to accomodate an entirely different school of level design, so it plays like a poorly done mod! Hooray!

Speaking of poorly done mods: Who loves ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ zombie levels? Because there's one chapter in The New Order that is all about moving forward and shooting shambling Nazi Zombies in their brains. Just walk through with a stompy robot and dual assault rifles, scoring headshots on all the zombies! It's like mowing the lawn, but WITH ZOMBIES! It's like doing the dishes, but with ZOMBIES! It's like sitting through a boring meeting, BUT WITH ZOMBIES!

So if you liked The New Order and need more, The Old Blood is there. If you haven't played The New Order, play that instead. Otherwise you're going to be wondering what the hell is so great about this new set of Wolfenstein games.

reviewText:
If you liked The New Order, then this is more of it. And by it I mean a bloody good game.
Story-wise a prequel to TNO, this game will take you (finally!) to and around Castle Wolfenstein and Wulfburg, and re-introduces the occult side of this alternate universe's Nazis.

First half of the game is getting to and from Castle Wolfenstein and is basically the same thing as the early parts of Tne New Order. There are a couple new weapons, notably the pipe which will become your best friend as you use it to climb, open stuff, fetch stuff and (of course) savagely kill Nazis. I thought there were more situations where you could go all stealthy and eliminate the commanders to avoid alarm, but that could've been the location of an ancient castle just feeling more like a place where you'd want to sneak. You can go loud anytime you want, of course.

In the second part, in Wulfburg, you'll be introduced to zombie Nazis just as the 'clear one area of Nazis and move to another' might become a wee bit stale. Also they're on fire. Killing a Nazi will make him burst in fire and turn into a zombie, which sets you up for one really great area where you snipe Nazis who then turn on those that still live, keeping the heat off you. For a large part of one chapter you control a sort of a Nazi mech and go berserk on the helpless master  race, alive and undead alike, turning them into a glorious clouds of gibs and blood.

The game consists of 2 parts, each with 4 chapters. The boss of the first part is technological in nature and the second part ends with a boss of occult origins.

There's a plenty of secrets, gold bricks hidden out of sight and whole rooms alike. If you liked the retro dream sequence in TNO, then you'll be glad to find quite a bit of beds in Old Blood, some on the main path and some in secret areas.

I'm really a big fan of this new rebooted Wolfenstein, and The Old Blood is an expansion/'dlc' done well.
Sloth Academy rating: 3.5 golden sloths.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a 2015 standalone prequel and expansion to the critically acclaimed and underrated game, Wolfenstein: The New Order (2014). A solid and terrific first-person shooter at its own right, The Old Blood doesn’t change much from The New Order in regards to gameplay mechanics. However, I personally enjoyed the gameplay mechanics even though it is, obviously, recycled from The New Order. The review applies to people who never played MachineGames’ vision of Wolfenstein or people who already had The New Order on the Steam Library. The question remains: Should I get The Old Blood and why?

The Old Blood takes place in Castle Wolfenstein (yes, literally) around 1946. The Nazis are winning the war over the Allies and you must stop them from declaring decisive victory. You play as William “B.J” Blazkowicz, an OSS agent who must infiltrate the Castle to gather intelligence on Deathshead’s Compound (where your arch nemesis resides) and assassinate him. Interestingly, the Old Blood takes place just before the prologue chapter in The New Order. There are interesting characters in The Old Blood, including notables such as Helga Von Schabbs and notable references from previous Wolfenstein titles. The story is pretty good and has great homage to Return to Castle Wolfenstein (2002) and the developers respectfully placed references that old school gamers would recognized.

The gameplay is simple: shoot and kill Nazis. That’s it. Nothing else. This may sound so typical for a first-person school and it is, but every Nazi you kill feels very satisfying. The weapons and character movement are great and highly outstanding. The walkthrough would last you around 4-6 hours, but there are some replay values on getting achievements or finding secrets. The best part in The Old Blood is revisiting Wolfenstein 3D by sleeping on a bed (which the beds are in secret areas). Finding the secrets will bring you great rewards and nostalgia. Alongside with the storyline to fulfill MachineGames’ lore on Wolfenstein, Old Blood offers “Challenge Mode” (or challenge maps) and it is really great. Kill the Nazis and accumulate points on reaching certain criteria for bronze, silver, or gold.

While The Old Blood has great merits, there are some negative attributes that has to be taken in consideration. First, the content doesn’t seem much but the storage requirements is insanely huge (all thanks to the iD Tech 5 engine), taking around 38 GB of your hard drive or SSD. This is roughly the same storage space as The New Order, but has fewer content. Individuals who have poor internet connection or low download speeds will have to exercise caution on installing and downloading the game (and wait for hours). The game engine is pretty and impressive, but the engine suffers frequent popup textures or objects were blurry and takes a few seconds to adjust itself to its proper graphical design. In my experience, this happens more often in The Old Blood than The New Order.

The Old Blood (standalone expansion/DLC) is outstanding and I really enjoy it. Even though there are many similarities for The New Order, there are some games that shouldn’t change gameplay mechanics and The Old Blood is one of those games. Game reviewers or critics gave The Old Blood some solid reviews (or “mixed” with many won’t recommend the “full price”). In my personal point of view, The Old Blood is absolutely worth $20 or your regional equivalent. MachineGames broke off the common trend of expensive DLCs (with little content) and gave a full fledge expansion that is reasonably priced and justified. I commend the developers for making the right choice. For those who have The New Order, but didn’t get The Old Blood, I strongly encourage you to get the game. For the gamers who have not experience Wolfenstein, get The Old Blood first for the story, then get The New Order. The Old Blood is my personal favorite for 2015 as one of the best expansion (or “DLC”) to the well-established, 2014 game – The New Order. On a good discount or full price, this standalone expansion is worth your money. Without a doubt.

- A remake realized with the narrative style of The New Order. This means BJ is extremely characterized, and there are many more important characters. This remake is placed as a perfect prequel of The New Order.
- There are zombies as in the 2nd episode of the original Wolf 3d!!!!!!! XD

---Cons---- The Zombies don't shoot from a third hand on their chest by waving their arms XD. I was almost going to put this as a Pro, but my Nostalgia took over... XD
- It's a shorter campaign, but considering it's an extra chapter... And it's cheap too...

reviewText:
The Old Blood was entertaining; I won’t deny that. But it feels like it belongs in 2003. It isn't old school enough to have the charm of 90s shooters, and isn't as forward looking as the shooters of 2004/2005 were. It's somewhere in the middle, where I don't think anyone would want to be.

The combat in The Old Blood is simplistic in a way that starting to feel unacceptable. I’m glad it isn’t Call of Duty, where the action is only slightly more sophisticated than Operation Wolf. But this is way behind F.E.A.R. and Crysis 1, which are still unmatched in “realistic” singleplayer FPS combat. The problem in Wolfenstein is that enemies aren’t capable of doing anything interesting. They run at you and sit behind cover, but don’t do much beyond that. This crude system works against the weaker enemies, who go down in 1 hit. But more powerful enemies provide the least interesting challenge possible, as all they do is take more hits to die, as if this was an RPG. This kind of design feels like the videogame equivalent of a Steven Seagal movie. Films where you can’t even expect to see interesting action choreography, let alone a good story.

Speaking of the story, The Old Blood doesn’t do much of anything interesting. You’re on a mission to retrieve some documents, and on the way to them you have to murder hundreds of Nazis and their pets. This story lacks the surprising humanity and warmth that The New Order exuded during its quieter moments. I guess because it’s a prequel, there was no room for any character development at all, as that was all present in the original game. You do meet some characters, but they don't get much room. It's only been a couple hours since I finished the game, and I can hardly remember any of them.

I don’t know what it is with ID Tech 5, but it seems to encourage the kind of art direction I enjoy. I played the DLC for The Evil Within just before diving into this, and as both use the same engine it was nice seeing the same qualities reflected in both. The use of lighting and color great. Even if the textures might look a bit rough, the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. The result is an image that looks almost better than it “should”.

Word leaked a while ago that a sequel is in the works. I hope they aim a bit higher than “the same, except better looking”. I mean I had reasonable fun, even if the story had loads of logical inconsistencies, and things like the climbing and swimming irritated me to no end. I just want more. I shouldn’t be thinking back to something I played in 2005 wishing I was playing that instead.

reviewText: Once again Machine Games delivers on an extremely enjoyable Wolfenstein experience. If you were among those who were curious as to how the Allies were able to find the secret location of Deathshead's compound, then this is what you have been waiting for. Once again you play as B.J. Blazkowicz that, alongside fellow OSA agent Richard Wesley, have been tasked with infiltrating the titular castle Wolfenstein in order to secure the documents that will reveal where Deathshead is hiding, but it won't be easy as he has to go up against early versions of the Ubersoldaten that are hooked to powerlines that while restricting them to a set patrol, can still be extremely dangerous. Like in The New Order, you can decide if you want to do it in a stealth or just go all guns blazing with dual wield rifles and whatnot. reviewText:
Wolfenstein : The Old Blood (TOB) is a Prequel to Last Year's favorite Wolfenstein : The New Order. (TNO)
A Small game but different and fun enough with the original formula to make it worth buying at the retail price point.

TOB, takes place directly before TNO as you infiltrate Castle Wolfenstein to find documents revealing Deathshead's Location. All of this takes you on a adventure that has you blasting and on occassion sneaking your way through enemies. If you've played TNO then your not missing much here, the weapon system is roughly the same except about half of them are completely different weapons, one of the most useful being the pipe. (Which is almost a character in itself, with the amount of time you'll be spent looking at it.) There is a small perk system, but its nothing again too huge and it doesn't become distracting either which is alright.

The enemies are roughly the same, with different asthetics for the time period. Except for the last 3 chapters of the game, which i won't spoil. (There are tons of clues, in particular if you look for a letter behind a bookcase then you'll see it from a mile away.) For example, your not going to see the Nazi Technology to the extent that they have in TNO, but it'll be prevelent. The gameplay remains tense and fast paced with the same if it aint broke, don't fix it attitude which i appreciate because the TNO's gameplay was slick and well polished. Shame about that underwhelming boss though its nothing compared to the boss of TNO. (The adds are honestly the hardest part of that fight.)

In terms of the story, it is on par with the level of quality you get from TNO and depending on your perspective its slightly more or less crazy as TNO too. You'll meet a few characters with pretty interesting backgrounds if you go out of your way to read them. B.J's classic badassery continues as he spends basically half of the game shirtless. I sh*t you not. He spends half of TOB fighting people half naked, which is awesome. His signature monologues from TNO return with a vengence, which this time reveal a bit more into his background story because TNO was so light on it.  The main antagonists are decent, and you get the occassional tense brush with them but they are just a part of the experience, just like the original.

So, in terms of game length i beat the game on hard in 5 hours and a half. Which for the price point is a really good sell for something i had an absolute blast with. I'd also like to mention you can get TOB bundled with TNO, so if you for some reason don't have them both, you can get them at the same price of retail TNO on steam. Which is a steal.

In Conclusion.

Solid and Fun, Recommended if you liked the original or if your curious at the price point. A nice challenge for the hardened fps veteran.

reviewText:
The Old Blood is definetly worth every penny. It's Wolfenstein done right, and I played many Wolfensteins. 1946 setting of the game (which we catched a glimpse in Prolouge in TNO) is very nice. You have those retro-futurisctic WWII weapons, by which you kill retro-futuristic nazi troopers, ubersoldaten und zombies. Weapons themselves feel powerfull and gunplay is just like in TNO, but smoother. The story is well presented and there are some interesting characters, thou sometimes I felt the story wanted to be something more emotional but played out... wierd... funny... IDK, maybe you'll get that while playing. And you should play it. I even recommend playing it before TNO (if you haven't been playing it). The game took me 10 hours to beat (67 % completion of game, so I guess there's still couple of hours to grind). Just like in TNO you have kilograms of gold to find, letters, secret areas (some neaty easter-eggs await you ;D). Another good thing is that there's less interactive cutscenes, more mowing down (or sneaking on) nazis, something which I did not like in TNO. There is nice addition of Challenges, in which you replay some big fights, but you get timer, points and combos, so the game may keep you for a while longer. It's also a very stable launch. I have never encountered any crashes or bugs, no framerate drops on medium-high settings even while shooting hordes of enemies. Overall Machinegames again gave us a great grame to experience and I think Wolfenstein franchise is in good hands.

GG Machinegames.

Talking about GG's. I think it's time for multiplayer Wolf?

reviewText:
If this isn't a Wolfenstein game, then I don't know what is...


When I first saw the trailer for this game, I knew it was a game I had to buy, especially because I had a very enjoyable time playing Wolfenstein: The New Order, the week that it came out. The price also seemed very appealing, as it was considerably cheaper, compared to its predecessor.

I am now writing this review, after just having finished the game on über difficulty. This took me about 8 hours to do, without really being in a hurry, as I did take some time to enjoy the scenery, and searching for the games many secrets.


Story & Gameplay:Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is in my opinion a very well thought out game, and while it doesn't have as much of a story, or as many developed characters as the New Order did, it certainly served its purpose and delivered the story very well.

The game is described as being a standalone prequel to the New Order, and I would without a doubt say that it is worthy to this description, the game can certainly stand on its own, and yet it leads very much up to what happens in the New Order.

Since this is a Wolfenstein game, you will without a doubt encounter alot of action, there will be alot of shooting, killing, and did I say Nazi killing? Yes this game is no different from its predecessors and certainly lives up to its name. However there is a few twists, but I rather not spoil it for you here, but I will say that this game is worth it.

You don't need to have played, Wolfenstein: The New Order prior to this game, as it stand very well on its own, and since this is supposed to be a prequel, I would even go as far to recommend that you play this game first.

Pros:
+ Blazkowicz
+ Good variety of weapons
+ Added replayability if you wish to unlock all the challenges, and find the hidden gold and letters.
Cons:
- The AI is still quite stupid, but this cant be said for most FPS games.

The Game:If you were able to run and play Wolfenstein: The New Order, then you should definietly be able to play this one too, and don't worry if you can't play the game on the highest graphic options, because this game comes with alot of settings, that you can adjust.

Pros:
+ Graphical pleasing ( but then again, I am not very hard to please ).
+ The game is very well optimized, and runs good on my PC.
+ Loading screens are quick, on my PC.
+ Lots of graphic options in the menu.
+ The Game is less blurry than Wolfenstein: The New Order
Cons:
- The mouse in the menu is acting weird.

reviewText: A very modest expansion to The New Order, which was probably one of the best singleplayer first person shooters I have played in a long time. This manages to take everything good about TNO and make it even better, as well as get rid of all the bad stuff. The voice acting was spotty at times in regards to Wesley, but other than that the performances were great. Something I really liked about TOB was the (very great) return to the occult, but it still kept a lot of the high-tech stuff from TNO - but prototypes. The guns were great, the perks were insanely useful this time around (instead of just increasing how much stuff you can carry), and the level design was essentially flawless. The writing was just as great as The New Order, but with a much different tone that was better fitting for this game.\n\nIt should be noted that this isn't a full game - but it's about half the size of Wolfenstein: The New Order. It does, however, come with a lot more side content. Bonus challenge maps, eight nightmare" levels (very nostalgic)
date: and a ton of collectibles make the campaign worth replaying. Honestly the only flaw with this is the megatextures
recommended: which make the world seem like it's made out of low-quality compressed jpeg images.\n\nTL;DR - It's worth the $20. Anything less is literally robbery. Also it has an actual grammar nazi."

reviewText:
A very short, but very sweet game.

The Old Blood plays like an over-the-top, condensed version of The New Order (Similar to what Blood Dragon did for the FarCry series).

The plot, setting and themes have been taken from Return To Castle Wolfenstein and reworked into a completely new Wolf experience.

There's enough secrets to find, challenging difficulties and arcade challenges to warrant a second playthrough.

The Old Blood is an excellent companion game to The New Order but ultimately if you weren't impressed by the latter, you won't find much to enjoy here.

Buy it if you enjoyed The New Order and want to extend that experience.

reviewText:
Return to Castle Wolfenstein is my second top ranked videogame ever.
Wolfenstein The New Order made me incredibly happy.
And The Old Blood did not leave me unsatisfied.
To be honest, it is not better than its predecessor (anybody expected it?). But it is very different in some ways, especially in gameplay itself. A lot of arena-style fighting waves of enemies (you can challenge your friends for highscore of course!), brand new decomposable rusty iron pipe and spectacular comeback of extremely cute nazi-zombies (well, shamblers, in this case).
Very entertaining high-voltage action and optinal stealth sections, where you can, do not worry, whip out anything you carry on your broad shoulders, is still there though. But you would not definitely recognize those old well known places, which quite dissapointed me. And no adult content this time (which dissapointed me as well).
Story is not as catchy as it was in The New Order and the final boss is.. Lousy, let´s say. The middle one has much more character. Not mentioned those from Wolf´s history. Which reminds me of nightmare levels and Hans Grösse..
So dann Guten Tag und Gute Nacht!
(And definitely don´t forget to check out great Mick Gordon´s Partisan! Maybe even better than Melissa Hollick´s I Believe.)

reviewText: A very modest expansion to The New Order, which was probably one of the best singleplayer first person shooters I have played in a long time. This manages to take everything good about TNO and make it even better, as well as get rid of all the bad stuff. The voice acting was spotty at times in regards to Wesley, but other than that the performances were great. Something I really liked about TOB was the (very great) return to the occult, but it still kept a lot of the high-tech stuff from TNO - but prototypes. The guns were great, the perks were insanely useful this time around (instead of just increasing how much stuff you can carry), and the level design was essentially flawless. The writing was just as great as The New Order, but with a much different tone that was better fitting for this game.\n\nIt should be noted that this isn't a full game - but it's about half the size of Wolfenstein: The New Order. It does, however, come with a lot more side content. Bonus challenge maps, eight nightmare" levels (very nostalgic)
date: and a ton of collectibles make the campaign worth replaying. Honestly the only flaw with this is the megatextures
recommended: which make the world seem like it's made out of low-quality compressed jpeg images.\n\nTL;DR - It's worth the $20. Anything less is literally robbery. Also it has an actual grammar nazi."

In this alternate timeline, the Second World War is not only still going, but the Nazis are winning due to supernatural advantages unearthed by Helga von Schabbs. reviewText: This prequel expansion to Wolfenstein: The New Order delivers little more than more of the same. But with a shooter as phenomenally solid as The New Order it's hard to pick a single bad thing about more. Once again the shooting is the tightest and the story and progression is a welcome surprise of quality. The only negative thing I could possibly say about this is that if you played through The New Order and loved its intense unrelenting firefights you may find some disappointment in The Old Blood as the highs are never quite as high octane as the previous incarnation. That said, it's still an incredibly solid shooter that shouldn't be missed by anyone who enjoys shooting dudes.
