reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to step into a totally 100 accurate WW2 game and mow down as many Nazi’s as you can? Then this might be the game for you. Accuracy not guaranteed.

Once again we take on the role of BJ Blazkowicz and see just how many bodies it takes to stop the Nazi war machine dead in its tracks, and let me tell you if my gameplay is anything to go by its an awful lot. With more guns than you thought anyone was capable of lugging around you shoot, cut, bash and blast your way through thousands of suicidal fascists, armoured hell beasts and supernatural ne'er-do-wells.

This game allows you to play it in one of several ways, no you don’t get a dialogue option to weasel your way out of fighting but what you do get is the choice to go quite, loud or ear drum burstingly psychotic. The guns themselves are a pretty standard lot ranging from silenced pistols to lead belching heavy machine guns and everything you would expect for an FPS in-between, the grenade pistol is a particular favourite of mine. The stealthy knife and pipe weapons, yes pipe, are great too and deliver very satisfying executions to anyone who has the misfortune of getting to close to you.

The enemies are not very diverse what with it being predominantly made up of Nazi grunts and a few odds and ends thrown in, at least in the first act, the second act offers some more variety and the particular satisfaction of setting one half of the mobs against the other before watching the ensuing firefight and chortling to yourself about how clever you are. There are also weak spots on a few of the enemies that lead to new and funsplosive ways to get rid of them, another joy of mine.

The world in which the game takes place is pretty great too. Starting off in a huge grandiose castle and ending up in the dank crypt of a rundown half destroyed German city with more horror in its history than most bio weapon corporations can dream of. I had a great deal of fun on my first playthrough exploring everything and making sure to find all the little secrets I could.

Speaking of secrets this game is riddled with collectables, logs and hidden levels. I enjoyed finding every one of them and the hidden retro levels were a joy unto their own. The other part of the game worth noting is the challenge arena. After progressing through enough of the game you unlock arenas allowing you to fight Nazi’s for a high score. Whilst initially I thought little of it I soon became obsessed with my gold medals and found that part to be almost as enjoyable as the main game itself.

The gameplay is great, snappy controls, fluid animations and awesome set pieces add up to a title you should get, especially if you liked New Order, FPS or just want to kick some evil ♥♥♥.

Have Fun ^_^

reviewText: Wolfenstein: The Old Blood isn't Wolfenstein: The New Order. The story is a throwback to older Wolfenstein games, Return to Castle Wolfenstein in particular. It's less alternative universe (though there's a touch of that, with mention of the Allies failing to take Normandy on D-Day) and more supernatural. So if you loved TNO for the story, Old Blood may not scratch the same itch.\n\nBut if you loved the gameplay in TNO, Old Blood is a great expansion. Plenty of content for an expansion and the new weapons are fun. The ability to stealth your way through sections is back, though you will have to fight your way out of many. There are perks to unlock by using particular weapons or by performing specific tasks. I wish all DLC was as good as The Old Blood.

reviewText:
What a game this is and in the true tradition of the series!

Do I recommend it, yes indeed and it is value to boot. I'm sure I will return for many more episodes and play as I think it was intended and that is before 'New Order'. This I would strongly suggest as the ending takes you to an introduction of what lies ahead. It is after all a 'Prequel' as you will find out.

Graphics are great as is the sound and the characters are all believable, the added mechanical beasts are a sensation and have you thinking how to get rid of them very quickly. The plot is solid with genuine storyline that will keep you entertained and offer up surprises regularly as well.

Take the time to look for treasures and secrets of which there are numerous, not always easy first time through but make the effort when you can. Lots to see and do which all add to the playability and gameplay enjoyment factor. Oh and make sure you take the time to have a sleep in one of the beds you encounter, you will find out why when you do.

Lets talk about 'Zombies'.....I hate 'Zombies'.....Well I did up until this game came a long and now I love 'em!.....Well, not actually love them but they add excellent content without seeming to appear just because everyone these days seems to think a game isn't a game unless it has them!

They are damn great fun and how they appear and come looking for you is well, a bit of a blast!

I have uploaded screenshots for both of the new 'Wolfies' so have a look and you will get a bit of an idea of what to expect and hopefully not spoil it for you.

Game took approx. 10 hrs to go through first time but I missed lots of items. Will take longer next time and will make sure to collect more. I would rate this game 7.5/10 and my screenshots will give you an indication of gameplay.

Conclusion, for all old and new Wolfenstein fans, buy it....Buy it....Buy it!....Pssst and don't forget 'New Order'!

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a prologue to The New Order, it offers us more of the same action while introducing a few new ideas, all in a smaller-sized (and reasonably priced) package.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=441250629

PROS:

-nice graphics and art style

-very good voice acting,the soundtrack-albeit somewhat muted at times-also accompanies the various game moments well

-nightmare levels are once again a fun throwback to the original game

-good story overall

-B.J. Blazkowicz remains a quite badass and likeable character,his empathy towards those he meets and his dry sense of humour are especially nice. It's really surprising how we started from a pixelated face in 1992 and got to a fully rounded character nowadays.

-interesting new weapon additions,also all the weapons remain useful through the whole campaign

-the level design is really good,and there's quite a few niches that,when explored,provide collectibles/extra pickups.

-levels are also quite different setting-wise,and this keeps things fresh.

CONS:

-the stealthy game beginning can be a bit boring

-climbing QTE (alternating mouse buttons) can grow a bit stale over time

-objective marker is very small and is sometimes easy to overlook

-nightmare levels can sometimes drag a bit

-textures aren't too sharp

-having to hit a key to pick ammunition up every time gets tiring eventually

I was overall impressed by this game,despite the overall smaller scope The Old Blood stands proudly as a very fun game,providing about 8 hours of entertainment and managing to maintain its predecessor's quality despite the lower budget. In fact being shorter probably makes it an even more intense and focused experience overall.
If you're looking for more Wolfenstein, more nazi shooting/stabbing and want to know the events that set up the story for The New Order then you can't really go wrong with this one.
I managed to get it at launch for about 10$, and I feel it was a steal at that price.

Gameplay:
Its Wolfenstein! In case for some reason you don't know what that means
column26: it means you are an awesomely stereotypical American hero that can impossibly dual wield machine guns and mow Nazi's (and their creations) down in waves and waves with blood everywhere in action packed sequences. The action is broken up by some stealth portions of the game. Most of the stealth is optional
column27: but some is not (more on that further below). This is exactly what you would expect from an expansion for The New Order. Its just plain simple fun action packed Wolfenstein gameplay. The gun-play is fluid and satisfying as ever. There are around 8 unique weapons
column28: and that's not counting grenades/throwing knives/temporary guns that you can pick up. Each gun has its use

etc. I can honestly say that throughout the entire game the gun-play never got tedious or boring for me.

There are also several beds in which you can sleep in that take you into the old retro "Escape From Castle Wolfenstein!" type levels. These are a fun and nostalgic 'game within a game' that appear throughout the story.

-

Sound/Music/Dialogue:
There is no real fast paced action/bass pounding/metal oriented music that plays during the fighting that was present in The New Order. It seems like they are going for more of an old school approach with the music
column34: and this is apparent as soon as you get to the menu screen. This isn't a bad thing
column35: its just noticeable when you are coming from The New Order which had the menu music that pumped you up giving you the feeling that Wolfenstein was back but in the modern day. The sounds/music that are in The Old Blood is more ambient and moody as you move throughout the prison/castle/town
column36: and definitely give you a more claustrophobic and desperate feeling as you progress. The scripted dialogue is about on par with what you would expect from a Wolfenstein game. Very vanilla goals with very stereotypical enemies and a very macho protagonist. What is new in this game however is the sort of "deep thought" dialogue that B.J. talks to himself with. This can range from really cool or "deep" little quotes

recommended: is playable as an easter egg) bits can easily translate to an extra 20+ hours of playtime.\nA solid and well-crafted FPS

reviewText: This is a prequel to Wolfenstein: The New Order, but unfortunately it is nowhere near as good. The story is very short (I've beaten it on the second highest difficulty in about 2,5 hours with little to no challenge) and there are few truly interesting characters (I liked Fergus in the New Order). Though I feel somwhat disappointed by the game, I would recommend buying it anyways, especially if you liked the New Order, - it is still a good shooter with lots of explosions, gore and a little stealth, but taking into account the little the game has to offer it would probably be better to wait for a discount.

reviewText:
Very enjoyable shooter, Very pretty graphics, smart enemies and nice weapons.
During the numerous set pieces you have the option of being stealthy and picking the enemies off one by one, or going in loud and proud.  Given that this is a more old school style game, no health re-gen, picking up health ammo manually it can get a bit frantic if you choose the loud option. But thats not necessarily a bad thing.

There is a hint of repetition in there, and there's never really a break from the action for long but its not a hugely long campaign.

If you liked the previous one, this half size half price stand alone expansion is a worthy purchase.

reviewText:
This game has absolutely no substance and I love it. Usually, when a simple call of duty style game comes out -- I simply won't care. Yet this game is charming. And the shooting -- It feels fantastic. I'm more of a bethesda open world rpg kind of gamer. I prefer stats and weapon mods and random loot and branching stories. Yet this game has absolutely none of that. With it's perfectly feeling weapons, great impacts, smooth movement, and fantastic and snappy animations this game brings back what you loved about first person shooters from the 90's and 2k's. And it does it better. Then inject a story that's far better than a game like this usually attempts, and you are left with something remarkable in the degree of excellence of it's execusion.

The grephics engine annoying, if you don't meet a certain spec, the game will stutter to keep things flowing, due to the open gl based idtech engine used in rage. One thing to pay attention to while setting the game up is that the extra effects, really don't make much of a difference. If you disable a lot of them the game won't look that different on low as it does on high. The reason is that one of the positives of id tech is that everything is pre baked. That's why the file size is so high. A lot of original streaming textures. This allows for a much more smooth, organic looking world than the usual dx11 titles with realtime engines. It's a different visual experience, with it's own pros and cons. Yet it's refreshing in a world where everyone is reusing the same handful of engines to have something truly new. Even if that new brings with it quirks.


I would highly recommend this game. It's extremely simple. Yet feels damn near perfect.


Perhaps we can get some rpg mechanics in the next one. I'd like just a pinch of depth next time. Keep those shooting mechanics though. Few games reach those heights.

reviewText:
Best $20 spent. Not even done with the campaign and I feel it necessary to write this review. Although, this review may not be as funny as some of the other ones out there, it's just my two-cents towards this game. I would completely recommend it to everyone. I had a blast playing it. :D

+ Dark theme (Like most of the Wolfenstein series)
+ Protagonist is best character NA
+ Guns are awesome to use (Especially the duel-wield)
+ Runs great on my PC set-up (Graphics are great, big bonus from 2001)

- Not a movie yet. ;-;

Only bug encountered so far is climbing ladders is sometimes a hassle (Was swimming around for 10 minutes trying to climb it .-.)

- Wouldn't kill Greta again
- Castle Wolfenstein needs some renovations

+ The scene where you're the waiter and Helga knows you're a spy.

reviewText: Machineworks and Bethesda still remember the good old days while adding the awesomeness of today. I'm talking about the fact the The Old Blood is an expansion like Blue Shift and Opposing Force were to Half-Life. It is well written, full of action and a complete addon to the original game. This is how downloadable content should be presented. The Old Blood, like The New Order, presents old fashion shooting with today's graphics. The gameplay is engaging, dynamic and never once did I feel bored. I think I might actually like The Old Blood more as it leans towards the paranormal side of the Wolfenstein franchise like Return to Castle Wolfenstein did, and that makes it such a good game. That is what The New Order missed in my opinion. The only con is the IDTech engine, well its graphics mostly. The game looks gorgeous but this texture thing while making swift turns breaks the immersion a bit. Otherwise I like the engine and works well for shooters such as these. It makes me look forward towards Doom 4.

reviewText:
I bought this in a bundle with The New Order. Whilst TNO looks great and plays OK, it feels sluggish and drawn out, reminiscent of Wolfenstein 2009. The Old Blood on the other hand is more than a return to form, revisiting the scenes from Return to Castle Wolfenstein. The ID Tech5 engine means it looks amazing, I found myself spending far too long admiring the scenery. With great pacing, ET ready weapons, plenty of Nazis to shoot, sneak em up gameplay for those less trigger happy and some great retro original 1993 Wolfie sections, I cant recommend this highly enough. Only criticisms are that the bosses are a bit too easy and there just isnt enough content, I know the price reflects that, so Im holding out hope for some DLC.

Fingers crossed that this will spawn a new era of Enemy Territory,  it has all of the ingredients to do just that. I lost 4 good years of my life to RTCW ET. I cant wait to do it all again!

reviewText:
I had a blast with this game. It's easy accessible, but challenging enough, filled with awesome and in-a-good-way-cheesy story elements. The game's humorous, but can even be seen through serious eyes. It's a perfect game to play  after a long day of work or school.

It's an old school shooter with varying and beautiful surroundings. Shooter-wise it's very polished. It's levels are direct and not open, but that is a good thing. It's fairly short, and unless you insist on collecting the secrets and all the trophies (achievements) it can be done in 10 hours or so.

So yeah, I recommend it, no doubt. I am actually missing its atmosphere and my character's awesome dialect now that I have finnished it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood follows on the heels of the excellent reboot, New Order and is of worthy your attention if you liked the earlier game. Being a stand alone budget priced title it doesn't have quite the length, but it still felt good to me. I just wrapped up the campaign as I type this, and my Steam library shows 13 hours played. You still have the ability to dual wield nearly any weapon in the game save for a few, and there is the option for stealth or run and gun with most levels. New Order really surprised me with it's emotional impact juxtaposed with the over the top combat and set pieces. The Old Blood has some of all of those but to a lesser degree. The ending of the game ties in very nicely with the beginning of New Order and leaves me wanting to replay that one immediately afterwards.

As far as technical issues go, I had no problems until I updated my AMD drivers and the AMD (Raptr) Gaming Evolved app installed itself. This title would simply not run until I uninstalled that. Other than that minor hiccup, it ran at a solid 60fps. For reference, I'm running an i5 3570k, 16gb RAM, and an R9 270x card.

Again, if  you liked New Order then I definitely recommend giving this one a close look.

reviewText:
I don't think I enjoyed this as much as I did The New Order, but if you haven't played TNO then I'd definitely recommend playing this first since it is a prequel; the end of The Old Blood rolls right up to the beginning of The New Order.

In TOB, you have stealth options, but I've found that stealth seems a bit more difficult in this game than others so consider that if you're looking for a challenge. I often blew my cover and ended up just having to run-and-gun, but it was fun. I think the only part I wasn't too fond of was the end boss, that turned into a chaotic cluster F.

The Old Blood must be one of the better-looking id Tech 5 games because I was actually impressed with how the textures didn't look like complete mush. The visuals were actually quite good but the cut scenes are ugly videos.

If you enjoyed TNO then you should like The Old Blood and if you haven't played TNO then you should start with this.

reviewText: I've said that Wolfenstein the New Order was my GOTY of 2014 and when I heard this stand alone expansion was coming out, I was gitty as a mother♥♥♥♥ing fat kid in a candy shop. reviewText:
For $20 it's pretty good. As a bundle with New Order? It's a friggin steal.

This makes for an excellent gaming double feature. I personally suggest playing Old Blood THEN New Order for a more cohesive narrative, and while they don't change much between the two titles gameplay wise, they both offer vastly different experiences. TNO has a MUCH stronger script and characters while TOB has much faster paced gunplay and level progression. In terms of content the story is less substantial (about 6-8 hours for most people as opposed to 12-15 in TNO) but it makes up for it with tons of secrets, choices, bonus modes, and tons of easter eggs you'll want to find and explore (Like a Skyrim Helmet and Wolfenstein 3D stages... no seriously).

This game is just a ton of fun and while TNO is better imo, as a straight shoot 'em up TOB is an amazing time that should keep you happy for 10-20 hours minimum if you love exploration or are completionist.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a standalone expansion pack for Wolfenstein: The New Order. This is a prequel, set in 1946, with WW2 still ongoing. BJ Blazkowicz is on a mission to infiltrate castle Wolfenstein to gather intelligence crucial to the war effort.

New Order was one of my favourite games of 2014 and possibly my favourite FPS of the last 10 years, combining outstanding shooting mechanics with a surprisingly good story. Old Blood isn't on the same level of awesome, but I did have some fun playing it.

What pleased me?
- Combat is fast paced and feels great.
- Key FPS mechanics are the same as New Order: health regenerates to the next multiple of 20%, find health packs to restore maximum, you can carry all the guns simultaneously, and you can dual wield most weapons.
- Controls are fully rebindable, aiming with mouse is very responsive.
- Intelligent Level design - some side paths, tunnels, etc allow for stealth. During a firefight, there are usually some opportunities to flank enemies or get above them - and the AI will try to do the same to you.
- No noticeable bugs or crashes.
- Smooth 60 FPS on my GTX 770 with most settings at high.

What disappointed me?
- Story is almost non-existent. New Order had several occasions where you'd go back to a hideout between missions, and be able to talk to the other members of the resistance. Old Blood has nothing like that. Just a couple of quick conversations with characters you never see again, and never feel any emotional connection to.
- Too short. The save file displays your playing time. I finished in 5 hours, 6 minutes and 17 seconds. There is a challenge mode, which plays like a basic horde mode on 10 maps extracted from the campaign, where the aim is to get a high score. I would have preferred a longer campaign.
- End boss has all the things I hate about videogame bosses. Avoid the repeated attack patterns while shooting the glowing weakspot? Check. I want to fight the boss but instead I spend most of the time shooting endlessly respawning minions, wasting my ammo, and distracting me from the boss' powerful attacks? Check.

Overall recommendation

If you like Wolfenstein or FPSes in general, you should enjoy Old Blood ... but you might want to wait for a 50% off sale.

It's less story driven so far, but attention to detail is simply stunning - plenty of really interesting information is given to you through collectibles and diaries, and you really wanna read them, because they contain vital information and paint a great picture for the whole operation"."

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood follows on the heels of the excellent reboot, New Order and is of worthy your attention if you liked the earlier game. Being a stand alone budget priced title it doesn't have quite the length, but it still felt good to me. I just wrapped up the campaign as I type this, and my Steam library shows 13 hours played. You still have the ability to dual wield nearly any weapon in the game save for a few, and there is the option for stealth or run and gun with most levels. New Order really surprised me with it's emotional impact juxtaposed with the over the top combat and set pieces. The Old Blood has some of all of those but to a lesser degree. The ending of the game ties in very nicely with the beginning of New Order and leaves me wanting to replay that one immediately afterwards.

As far as technical issues go, I had no problems until I updated my AMD drivers and the AMD (Raptr) Gaming Evolved app installed itself. This title would simply not run until I uninstalled that. Other than that minor hiccup, it ran at a solid 60fps. For reference, I'm running an i5 3570k, 16gb RAM, and an R9 270x card.

Again, if  you liked New Order then I definitely recommend giving this one a close look.

reviewText: I found this to be much better than The New Order despite all the reviews saying otherwise. The story was more memorable, the envionments were better. It seemed to borrow quite alot from Where Eagles Dare in the first few levels combined with some Indiana Jones and its Ahnenerbe element. Its very reminiscent of Return to Castle Wolfenstein and reminded me why I liked  it so much to begin with. The pipe addition wasn't memorable and its usage seemed very forced and gimmicky. It could have been left out entirely and very well might have been better for it. All in all it was well worth it even for full price and it had more content than I expected it to.\n\n10/10

reviewText:
If you played Wolfenstien: The New Order, you pretty much know what to expect. However, for those unfamiliar with it, playing TNO isn't mandatory since it's a prequel.

The game is a FPS, that takes place during WWII along an alternate timeline, where the Nazis have perfected robotics, cybernetics and weapon-tech. Meaning you will find yourself battling robotic super soldiers, cyborgs and well equipped soldiers eager to tear your head off.

While the game is a FPS, it does have many stealth elements. Sure, you can run in guns blazing and possibly survive. However the safer, and in my opinion way more fulfilling, is stealthing your way through certain locations. Why blast a heavily armored super soldier when you can sneak through some air ducts and get behind him to shut off his power? Why run through a kennel and battle cyborg dogs when you can sneak up to them while they sleep and silence them quickly?

No matter which route you go, if you are a fan of W:TNO, or FPS games in general you will probably love this game. It's not without it's faults though which I will list below, but first allow me to tell you what it does well.

ProsFlawless controller support
Incredibly long for a 20 dollar game
Breathtaking graphics
Excellent voice acting
Fantastic Storyline
Vent Crawling!
Good variety of enemies
Challenging gameplay with adjustable difficulty levelsConsNo Multi-player
Inadequate Tutorial
Not much replay value.
Occasionally the AI can be a bit dimwitted
No manual save
RATING: 7/10

reviewText:
I had a blast with this game. It's easy accessible, but challenging enough, filled with awesome and in-a-good-way-cheesy story elements. The game's humorous, but can even be seen through serious eyes. It's a perfect game to play  after a long day of work or school.

It's an old school shooter with varying and beautiful surroundings. Shooter-wise it's very polished. It's levels are direct and not open, but that is a good thing. It's fairly short, and unless you insist on collecting the secrets and all the trophies (achievements) it can be done in 10 hours or so.

So yeah, I recommend it, no doubt. I am actually missing its atmosphere and my character's awesome dialect now that I have finnished it.

reviewText:
I don't think I enjoyed this as much as I did The New Order, but if you haven't played TNO then I'd definitely recommend playing this first since it is a prequel; the end of The Old Blood rolls right up to the beginning of The New Order.

In TOB, you have stealth options, but I've found that stealth seems a bit more difficult in this game than others so consider that if you're looking for a challenge. I often blew my cover and ended up just having to run-and-gun, but it was fun. I think the only part I wasn't too fond of was the end boss, that turned into a chaotic cluster F.

The Old Blood must be one of the better-looking id Tech 5 games because I was actually impressed with how the textures didn't look like complete mush. The visuals were actually quite good but the cut scenes are ugly videos.

If you enjoyed TNO then you should like The Old Blood and if you haven't played TNO then you should start with this.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a standalone expansion pack for Wolfenstein: The New Order. This is a prequel, set in 1946, with WW2 still ongoing. BJ Blazkowicz is on a mission to infiltrate castle Wolfenstein to gather intelligence crucial to the war effort.

New Order was one of my favourite games of 2014 and possibly my favourite FPS of the last 10 years, combining outstanding shooting mechanics with a surprisingly good story. Old Blood isn't on the same level of awesome, but I did have some fun playing it.

What pleased me?
- Combat is fast paced and feels great.
- Key FPS mechanics are the same as New Order: health regenerates to the next multiple of 20%, find health packs to restore maximum, you can carry all the guns simultaneously, and you can dual wield most weapons.
- Controls are fully rebindable, aiming with mouse is very responsive.
- Intelligent Level design - some side paths, tunnels, etc allow for stealth. During a firefight, there are usually some opportunities to flank enemies or get above them - and the AI will try to do the same to you.
- No noticeable bugs or crashes.
- Smooth 60 FPS on my GTX 770 with most settings at high.

What disappointed me?
- Story is almost non-existent. New Order had several occasions where you'd go back to a hideout between missions, and be able to talk to the other members of the resistance. Old Blood has nothing like that. Just a couple of quick conversations with characters you never see again, and never feel any emotional connection to.
- Too short. The save file displays your playing time. I finished in 5 hours, 6 minutes and 17 seconds. There is a challenge mode, which plays like a basic horde mode on 10 maps extracted from the campaign, where the aim is to get a high score. I would have preferred a longer campaign.
- End boss has all the things I hate about videogame bosses. Avoid the repeated attack patterns while shooting the glowing weakspot? Check. I want to fight the boss but instead I spend most of the time shooting endlessly respawning minions, wasting my ammo, and distracting me from the boss' powerful attacks? Check.

Overall recommendation

If you like Wolfenstein or FPSes in general, you should enjoy Old Blood ... but you might want to wait for a 50% off sale.

reviewText:
For those of you who were absent from 2014 gamingwise, I don't blame you. Most of the games coming out were complete ♥♥♥♥ing disasters like Assassin's Creed Unity and The Crew or horribly disappointing like Watch_Dogs and Destiny, the latter I'm still kind of mad about. It was a very underwhelming year, to say the least, but there were a few games from big devs that managed to be good, one of which was Wolfenstein: The New Order. Wolfenstein: The New Order was a glorified shooter that has shamed pretty much all and any shooters from the last year or two with awesome gunplay, extremely gory Nazi killing, and characters with actual personality, which was a welcome break from whatever Call of Duty came out that year, which had... Kevin Spacey I think. I guess they decided they wanted to do a prequel story, so they made it and sold it for $20. How was it? Well, we're here to figure that out, aren't we? So let's see.

STORY: You are once again B.J. Blaskowitz, a red, white, and blue blooded soldier who, along with his associate Wesley, infiltrate Castle Wolfenstein, a German controlled castle that contains plans on where General Deathshead's compound is. The files are held by archaeologist Helga Von Schabbs, who is looking for something related to King Otto I. ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan, both are arrested, and B.J. has to escape, get Wesley, meet with their contact, and get the files from the archaeologist. Oh yea, and Nazi Zombies come in somewhere halfway through the story. It's nowhere as good as The New Order, takes a lot of elements from that story like that choice in the beginning that everyone who played the game knows what I'm talking about, this time happening in the mid-late game, but it isn't really that bad. Not as compelling, bit sillier and harder to take seriously than TNO, but it's still alright. Kept me interested long enough.

GAMEPLAY: Still the same great gunplay from the last game. Can dual wield a lot of weapons and it's fun to shoot Nazi's in the head. This time around, stealth is actually a viable option for these levels, which is nice as well. Weapons are good, we have a few new guns like the kamphpistole, which is a pistol with explosive rounds, and a pretty kickass sawed off shotgun. Overall, I can't complain.

GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCE: Game looks good as always, didn't notice any differences between New Order and this one. Castle Wolfenstein looks nice, as well as the other places. Does the same performancewise, I'd say, ran fine enough, even my ♥♥♥♥ PC can run it fine enough.

CHARACTERS AND VOICE ACTING: B.J is back, he's kind of the monologuey guy that he was before, but he's fine. The villians and the Nazi's are decently voiced as well, they speak German for the most part, so bonus points for authenticity there. No bad performances, so nothing to complain for it really.

FINAL VERDICT: Not as flashy or impressive as The New Order, I recommend picking that up before this. Still, it is a decent game, not a must buy like TNO, but still alright. 7.5/10, pick it up if you liked The New Order or if it goes on sale for a really good deal.

Ich bein ein 'hot dog'

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood shows the story before The New Order. It's pretty interesting BUT it's too damn short.
I know that this is only a prequel,  and it's just a technological preview of the enigne that will be behind DOOM and other games but I've finished the entire campaing in UBER difficult in 5 hours straight. I mean the caster itself is too damn easy and they should had create more intensive combact especially inside the castel.

PROs:

- Exceptional Graphic
- Excellent Story, the classic Wolfenstein Story
- Good Gameplay mechanics

CONs:

- TOO Damn short, even on uber difficult.
- The Zombies part is full of stuttering and lags, too many effects I think (even with 980ti the FPS will drop)
- Enemy too stupid
- The storyboard is too linear and easy to understand
- Enemies are too easy to predict

Can I reccomend this game? Yes and No.
If you would like to finish the story, and understand how they started the New Order then YES.
If you would spend 20 bucks for a 5 hours gameplay then YES.
If you want to buy this game to revive the previous one then NO.
If you are seeking for more challenging then NO.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood Review: Type A Positive

Wolfenstein: The New Order released last year to a high degree of critical acclaim. Fans of the franchise loved it and, as I am evidence of, it drew a significant number of new people into the shoes and crew cut of Blaskowicz. With the strong footing of The New Order as its backbone, the stand-alone The Old Blood seeks to expand upon the pseudo-reboot's immersive world and cast of characters.

The events of The Old Blood, without giving too much away, take Blaskowicz through a host of different areas, each with their own distinctive tone and color palette; large stone structures feel cold and foreboding, burning cities fill the player with increased levels of panic and stress, and underground caverns and ruins pluck the strings of the wary explorer that all gamers have within their hearts. However, no environment feels out of place in the alternate timeline. The art design and graphical fidelity maintain the quality presented in The New Order, making the stand-alone game feel like a cohesive part of the larger experience.

Along his journey Blaskowicz encounters a host of new characters, but since this is a cheaper experience and therefore shorter, none of them are capable of being developed into people you care about or truly fear. There are definitely moments where the game screams, YOU SHOULD FEEL BAD THAT THIS IS HAPPENING" but there simply isn't enough time to form a significant bond with any of them. The same goes for the villains. Their appearances are few enough that tension has no time to build
date: and your hatred for them is nowhere near smoldering
recommended: despite them being interesting enough. Although the characters themselves may have been lacking
hoursPlayed: the ridiculous and criminally badass events that unfold more than make up for it. The end of the game even ties in directly to the opening events of The New Order which
voteText: as a fan of the game
helpfulPercent: I very much appreciated.\n\nRead the rest of my review at http://casualsgaming.com/2015/05/18/wolfenstein-the-old-blood-review-type-a-positive/"

reviewText:
If you played Wolfenstien: The New Order, you pretty much know what to expect. However, for those unfamiliar with it, playing TNO isn't mandatory since it's a prequel.

The game is a FPS, that takes place during WWII along an alternate timeline, where the Nazis have perfected robotics, cybernetics and weapon-tech. Meaning you will find yourself battling robotic super soldiers, cyborgs and well equipped soldiers eager to tear your head off.

While the game is a FPS, it does have many stealth elements. Sure, you can run in guns blazing and possibly survive. However the safer, and in my opinion way more fulfilling, is stealthing your way through certain locations. Why blast a heavily armored super soldier when you can sneak through some air ducts and get behind him to shut off his power? Why run through a kennel and battle cyborg dogs when you can sneak up to them while they sleep and silence them quickly?

No matter which route you go, if you are a fan of W:TNO, or FPS games in general you will probably love this game. It's not without it's faults though which I will list below, but first allow me to tell you what it does well.

ProsFlawless controller support
Incredibly long for a 20 dollar game
Breathtaking graphics
Excellent voice acting
Fantastic Storyline
Vent Crawling!
Good variety of enemies
Challenging gameplay with adjustable difficulty levelsConsNo Multi-player
Inadequate Tutorial
Not much replay value.
Occasionally the AI can be a bit dimwitted
No manual save
RATING: 7/10

reviewText:
I thought I was buying a run and gun shooter in the spirit of doom and the original father wolfenstein.

Turns out this is actually a Vet Simulator.

The aim of the game is to put as many dogs out of their misery as you can before you get shot by sadistic nazis.

Despite this vital flaw of missing information from the steam store page, do not let this put you down. It's an excellent game, full of clever design and high octane action and well worth a purchase.


10 dogs out of 10, would put my life on the line for armoured puppies again

reviewText:
NOTE: This review contains some information about one of the boss battles in part 1 that might be considered a spoiler - I talk a bit about how to beat the boss in the contex of discussing a bug. I don't spoil the story or anything about the level.

TL:DR summary at end
----

I really loved the New Order and thought it was probably the best single-player shooter since the first Crysis. The Old Blood is more of the same style of gameplay, but assembled in a less interesting manner. I really struggled whether to give this a recommended or not recommended, but ultimately the good just barely outweighs the bad.

The Old  Blood tells the story of what B.J. Blaskowicz was doing immediately before the assualt on Deathshead's compound that opens The New Order. B.J. has to infiltrate Caslte Wolfenstein to steal a folder that contains the location of this compound. Of course, things aren't that simple and B.J. has to escape the castle and fight his way through hordes of human, robotic, and supernatural enemies to survive.

The Good:

-The shooting is great, actually better than TNO. They've added a mash r to reload faster" mechanic which really gives the firefights a frantic tension. You can still dual-wield everything
date: which is awesome. I also liked using the pipe as a weapon and really enjoyed the grenade-lauching pistol
recommended: which is ultra-powerful but has scarce ammo. Just like in The New Order
hoursPlayed:
the shooting is so much fun that it makes up for the significant problems with the game.

-Excellent voice acting and characterization. The two main villans are especially compelling and better-written than Deathshead from TNO.

-Stays in first person the entire time (excepting the very beginning and ending) which helps with immersion.

-NPC design and the overall art design of the game is fantastic - Castle Wolfenstein has never looked cooler.

-Good AI. Enemies will flush you out with grenades and try to flank you. You can't just stand behind some cover and take pot shots because they will sneak up behind you.

-Great music
voteText: just like in TNO.\n\n-The difficulty is less spiky in this game. I beat both this and TNO on the "I Am A God of Death" difficulty
helpfulPercent: but while TNO felt like long stretches of very easy (but fun) sneaking around combined with occasional near-impossible boss fights
votesHelpful:
TOB is more consistently difficult run and gun (at least on the hard difficulties).

The Bad:

-Level design. This is the biggest area in which TOB falls short of the standard established by TNO. While the levels in TNO were all open environments that you could approach with a mix of stealth
votesTotal: sniping
votesFunny: and full frontal assault
commentsCount: the levels in TOB generally consist of a linear path between shooting gallery-style arenas. The arenas themselves are usually big and open
column16: but you typically can't avoid getting detected within a few seconds of entering
column17: so you're forced to use a run-and-gun approach nearly all the time. In the final level
column18: I even kept getting "detected" when I was hiding in a cave out-of-view of any enemies
column19: and I hadn't even killed anybody
column20: so there weren't any bodies to find. It felt like it was scripted. There are a few areas
column21: such as a cable car station and a graveyard
column22: where you're able to be stealthy
column23: but these are few and far between.  There's also a very linear stealth section at the beginning that's finicky to the point of annoyance.\n\n-Performance is considerably worse than TNO. I was able to play TNO maxed out on my i5-3470/970 system and get 60 fps 95% of the time. This game has more PC options (like various levels of AA and SSAO) but I wasn't able to keep a constant 60 even with AA X2
column24: SSAO on medium
column25: LOD Bias on medium
column26: and PPF at minimum. I frequently saw drops to about 50 fps when lots of NPCs were on the screen
column27: and during the final boss fight things got so intense it dropped below 30 and I had to knock everything down to medium just to make the game playable. This is extra frustrating considering the Id Tech 5 engine has terrible textures and looks 5 years out of date.\n\n-Several frustrating bugs. Most notably
column28: I had a bug where I couldn't get out of the first area because a scripted ladder drop repeatedly failed to occur. I had to reboot the whole system to get it to work.\n\nI also had what seemed like a bug with a boss fight near the end of Part 1. This is part of a sequence where you fight a Supersoldier and then immediately fight another boss. The game auto-saves between the two bosses. After you fight the super-soldier
column29: you can pick up his heavy gun and use it to fight the other boss. I didn't do this during my first attempt at the second boss
column30: because I thought I was going to just be able to run around the second boss and escape. Then
column31: when I re-loaded at the beginning of the second boss fight
column32: the supersoldier's heavy gun was gone. I tried to beat the boss about 60 times without it
column33: but failed. Then I looked up several playthroughs on Youtube and saw that the boss could be beaten fairly easily with the supersoldier's gun. It seems like that's what the game intends for you to do
column34: so why doesn't the game give you the heavy gun when you respawn?\n\nI ended up having to turn it down to easy to get past this particular section. By contrast

column36:
so I don't think it's me sucking.

TL:DR SUMMARY

Better than your average Call of Duty campaign

reviewText:
If you have played The New Order(TNO) to death and just wants to experience new Wolfenstein content but with the same high paced and excellent gunplay that TNO offered or maybe you are unsure if you will enjoy TNO or can't afford spending 50€ on it.

Then Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is the game for you!

Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is an expandalone that offers more of the same at a lower pricepoint without comprimising quality or gameplay. It offers a more compressed campaign (took me 5h to complete) full with fast paced gunplay, an intresting storyline and environments.

This is another excellent Wolfenstein game from Machinegames!

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a standalone FPS from Wolfenstein: The New Order. Both games are done very well and are highly enjoyable.

PROS:
+ Satisfying weaponry
+ Fluent physics
+ Incredible graphics
+ Beautiful level build and design
+ Loads of action

CONS:
- The story has a somewhat disappointing plot-twist
- Relatively short gameplay for the price
- You need a very good PC to run it smoothly (not actually a con if you have a good one)

Anyone looking for a game full of action, stealth and sweet mapping: get this game.

My rating: 8.5/10
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a great pre-quel with modern day graphics, gunplay, and mechanics to go with the original story from the 2001 Return to Castle Wolfenstein game. The story itself is great but there are moments in the story/main campaign that feel a bit dull, luckly there aren't that many dull moments that detracts people from the main points of the story. The developers have even added hidden 'Nightmare levels' within each level of the campaign for a nostalgia trip back to the original 2d version of Wolfenstein. The only short comings I have with Wolfenstein: The old Blood is some replayability with the game and missed oppurtunities from the developers. The replayability in this game narrows down to replaying the story mode and challenge levels where story mode is the same thing over again, some people may enjoy this more than I did, and challege levels that don't feel rewarding to players who want to achieve Uber gold medals. The developers could have added Return to Caslte Wolfenstein and the original 2d wolfenstein games after completing the main story giving more replayability and even discovery for people who haven't played either of the two. I would recommend this game on a steam sale, free if you pre-order Doom, more than a full $20 (US) price because the short comings and amount of replayability the game has to offer will have some players feeling a bit of buyers remorse.

reviewText:
Product received for free

In short, if you liked the gameplay in The New Order, you'll enjoy this too. Just don't expect too much from the story.

Pros:
-Amazing graphics
-Fun and challenging gameplay
-Partially destructable and very detailed environments
-Tons of collectibles
-You get to kill lots of Nazis, and you feel like a badass doing it

Cons:
-Story is pretty light, characters aren't very interesting or developed
-The weapon wheel is a bit awkward
-The bosses are too easy once you know how to beat them
-Nazi zombies...
-Very short, I beat the main story in under 5 hours

Overall, I would definitely say that this game is worth it, though considering how short it is it might not be a bad idea to wait for a sale.

reviewText: Haven't finished The Old Blood yet but my initial impressions after about 3 hours are very good. I thoroughly enjoyed Wolfenstein the New Order and this is more of the same awesome game play with new areas, guns, enemies and textures. Been playing on a headset and the voice acting and sounds are very immersive. There are a variety of guns all of which feel really good and offer a variety of game play... the stealth mechanic in this game actually works very well if you want to play that way and sneak around. I however am a run and gun player and prefer rolling in with 2 assault rifles equipped, glad to have the options though, some situations require more stealth. A new add is the pipe wrench which is used a lot to climb walls and access various places. Graphics on the Id Tech 5 engine are my favorite out there, loved them since the release of Rage, textures and character models are top notch. Plenty of secrets, tidbits like a Doom Cacodemon in a laundry hamper and documents and things lying about to read and add some depth and story. Loving it, would definitely recommend to any gamer that is a fan of shooters.

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a standalone prequel to Wolfenstein: The New Order.  As TNO was suspiciously lacking in the Castle Wolfenstein department, TOB fills in that gap.  Gameplay is largely the same with Machine Games' modern take on classic FPS gameplay style and it still works great.

TOB is a step backwards in some areas, but also brings the game closer to the classic Return to Castle Wolfenstein.  Gameplay is not as varied as TNO but still retains the same high quality.  Most of the game takes place in the castle or very similar locations as opposed to the variety of locations found in TNO.  This game is also lacking the large story choice offered in TNO.  A similar choice is offered late in the game here but has almost no impact on the game.  TOB does add one new weapon, a sort of explosive flare gun, as well as revamping the upgrade system so thankfully previous upgrades are no longer required to make progress on later ones.

Along with largely taking place in Castle Wolfenstein and the surrounding area, TOB brings back the nazis' persuit of the occult.  I probably shouldn't say more at risk of spoilers.  The story is written as well as TNO, though it is significantly shorter as expected for a release at 1/3 the price.  It still manages to be as long as the majority of full price FPS releases (depending on how you play of course,) putting them all to shame again.  In addition there is a new challenge mode which lets you replay some larger fights throughout the game to try to get the best score.

The one big problem this game has is performance.  Compared to TNO, I find myself needing to turn a few more settings down to stay at 60 fps and still drop below that during cutscenes and in a few specific places.  The final boss even dropped me down to about 35.  This by itself wouldn't be THAT much of a problem, just a bit of an optimization problem, but just like TNO the game stutters badly any time it drops below 60 fps.  I have yet to figure out what causes this or how widespread it is, but the general performance problems are very common and do not seem to be lessened by more powerful video cards.

Compared to TNO, this game isn't quite as good but it still shines compared to other FPSs.  Do yourself a favor and play them both.

reviewText:
THE SHORT SHARP REVIEW

THE POINTY END
+ 16 hours for $16.00 AUD (green man gaming)
+ Runs flawlessly @ 2560x1600 on i7-3820 w/ Dimmdrive and 32 gig of ram
+ Implemented faded texture feature virtually elminates pop-in effect.
+ Prequel story on par with Wolfenstein: The New Order. The english letter writing is excellent.
+ Locations/Textures are top notch quality, interesting and varied.
+ Characters have full facial animation and friendly's are likably. Great voice acting.
+ Nearly every chapter has a secret wolfenstien 'old school' level to play through.
+ The new order weapons cross over here, with a few additions.
+ Collectable gold, artwork, secret areas, letters to read,
+ Several challenges w/ leaderboards included during and after you finish the game.

HOLD ONTO THIS
- Waiting for tne sequel after the new order

reviewText:
First Playthrough Impressions:
A suprisingly fun shooter.
Better than New Order.
Why you do not need much of a story in a FPS.

Cons or Pros, really its a matter of perspective.

-some very small zones between savepoints.
-tunnelling of enemies to your entrenched/roving position.
-not alot of plot (nothing even close to New Order)
-It rains Nazis.
-Fake Static
-Cross Intellectual Property advertising/tie-ins
-A expressive variety of structural zones expressing the options available to a design team within a shooter; excepting large vertical zones.
-Large swaths of gameplay elements photocopied from first and second Wolfenstein games. References to New order included. Mythic Dawn is not included.
-The gameplay is rational and self explanatory
-My total gametime for the first playthrough racked up eight hours.
-It's not 'hard'.

Is fun, do get play.

reviewText:
The Old Blood is a standalone prequel expansion to The New Order and it is half the length.

Right off the bat, if you played TNO already it has that familiar feel while introducing a new mechanic. You now can use a pipe to take down enemies, climb walls and open hatches. That's pretty much the only new addition in terms of gameplay - everything else is pretty similar. The weapons you get are mainly the old versions of your set in TNO, so there are no dual fires, which makes sense. You do get some new weapons like the Kampfpistol - a single-fire pistol with a grenade projectile, Bombenschuss - sniper rifle, and Schockhammer - shotgun. All enemies encountered in TNO are currently in their prototype stages here, which is also cool to compare.

The game again gives you the choice to play through the chapters stealthily or balls to the walls, however it does highly encourage stealth gameplay. It's all in how you want to play, though, so don't let the stealth-themed introduction throw you off. It contains eight chapters and five difficulty levels. Plenty of perks to aquire that add to the replayability.

If you enjoyed any other previous Wolfenstein title, it's a must-buy.

Personal Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
Simply amazing! Great stroy line along with graphics. Running this on a GT 750 and it looks great. I cant complain about anything. This game runs smooth on my build.
The developers sure didn't hold back on the gore and language. The melee combat is the best. Up close and personal. Choose to use a two piece pipe or a knife with many different CQC scene outcomes. CQC aganist the dogs is even brutal. Sometimes you have no idea when a dog jumps in your face and next thing you know your stabbing 7-10 times at its neck :) The weapons are sharp and inflict a lot of damage if done right. You can of course throw knives and gernades. You can even dual weild assult rifles and shotguns along with sliencer pistols.
I'm playing it on normal and I find it very challenging! The AI is smart and will flank you and push you out of corners.
I'm no fan of the Nazi era but I do admire the SS uniforms and gear. In this game the Nazi gear and equipment you have to go up aganist is frighting and puts you on the edge.
You have two chocies, either sneak and use stealth attacks or simply enter a room blazing. The choice is yours! If your caught sneaking its no big deal just be ready to take on some heavy heat.
The more you advance into the game the more upgrades you unlock such as extended clips and Armor/Health boosts.
You can collect gold bars and treasure along the way among other things to achieve more stuff. Lots of secret and hidden content to be found as well.
The BEST thing so far *to me* is each chapter you will find a wine bottle. Drink it....It will take you back to you younger days of Wolfenstein 3D with The Old Blood" weapons and full 360deg mouse movement. I hope you remember your way around the first level of W3D! After you complete the old school level you will return to The Old Blood.
Graphics 10/10
Combat  10/10
Story      10/10
Legitness 1000/10

I highly recomment this game to any old school Wolfenstein fan or any new commer. ( I have yet to play New World Order) Thats next for me.
Overall can't beat the price for such a well put together game.
I honestly did Nazi this comming did Jew?

Have fun and slaughter as many filithy pigs as you can!"

Although I wasn't too pleased with the emphasis put on stealth in the first 2 levels and the lack of main characters. Also pretty much every character in the game ends up dying which was some what displeasing.

Over all I enjoyed it, felt great when I put Helga out of her evil Nazi misery then
was recued by Fergus. I was like aaaaw ♥♥♥♥♥ this is where The New Order starts. I loved this game so much and the Nazi zombies really brough me back to the older game Castle Wolfenstein. So many feels went through me, New Order was great but I loved the 5+ hours I spent playing this more than I did The New Order.

Definitely check this game out! Especially if your a fan of The New Order!

reviewText: Wow!What can I say? I just finished this game. This was a great standalone DLC for Wolfenstein. reviewText:
I'm still struggling to understand why more games can't play like Wolfenstein. The gameplay is incredibly addictive and fluent and nothing ever feels buggy. First of all, I would like to say that The New Order and The Old Blood has easily made their way into my top 10 games. This is what I would call SOLID games.

Here's what The Old Blood has to offer:
- Unlockable Perks
- Challenge Mode
- Collectibles
- A few new guns
- New characters
- Old characters
- Nightmare levels
- Backstory

The two games play exactly the same, with one or two elements changed or added. Playing The Old Blood made me long for The New Order. This is because the game lacks story depth and character developement, but I suppose it's only fair since it's a DLC. It's certainly not as well versed as The New Order, but it's one of the best DLCs I have ever experienced. Most DLCs just feels like add-on content that should have been in the game but wasn't because it was unfinished. I would recommend playing the prequel first if you are looking for chronological order, but playing it second has a bunch of perks as well.

Bottom line: If you loved The New Order, you will most probably love The Old Blood as well!

reviewText:
First Playthrough Impressions:
A suprisingly fun shooter.
Better than New Order.
Why you do not need much of a story in a FPS.

Cons or Pros, really its a matter of perspective.

-some very small zones between savepoints.
-tunnelling of enemies to your entrenched/roving position.
-not alot of plot (nothing even close to New Order)
-It rains Nazis.
-Fake Static
-Cross Intellectual Property advertising/tie-ins
-A expressive variety of structural zones expressing the options available to a design team within a shooter; excepting large vertical zones.
-Large swaths of gameplay elements photocopied from first and second Wolfenstein games. References to New order included. Mythic Dawn is not included.
-The gameplay is rational and self explanatory
-My total gametime for the first playthrough racked up eight hours.
-It's not 'hard'.

Is fun, do get play.

reviewText:
Simply amazing! Great stroy line along with graphics. Running this on a GT 750 and it looks great. I cant complain about anything. This game runs smooth on my build.
The developers sure didn't hold back on the gore and language. The melee combat is the best. Up close and personal. Choose to use a two piece pipe or a knife with many different CQC scene outcomes. CQC aganist the dogs is even brutal. Sometimes you have no idea when a dog jumps in your face and next thing you know your stabbing 7-10 times at its neck :) The weapons are sharp and inflict a lot of damage if done right. You can of course throw knives and gernades. You can even dual weild assult rifles and shotguns along with sliencer pistols.
I'm playing it on normal and I find it very challenging! The AI is smart and will flank you and push you out of corners.
I'm no fan of the Nazi era but I do admire the SS uniforms and gear. In this game the Nazi gear and equipment you have to go up aganist is frighting and puts you on the edge.
You have two chocies, either sneak and use stealth attacks or simply enter a room blazing. The choice is yours! If your caught sneaking its no big deal just be ready to take on some heavy heat.
The more you advance into the game the more upgrades you unlock such as extended clips and Armor/Health boosts.
You can collect gold bars and treasure along the way among other things to achieve more stuff. Lots of secret and hidden content to be found as well.
The BEST thing so far *to me* is each chapter you will find a wine bottle. Drink it....It will take you back to you younger days of Wolfenstein 3D with The Old Blood" weapons and full 360deg mouse movement. I hope you remember your way around the first level of W3D! After you complete the old school level you will return to The Old Blood.
Graphics 10/10
Combat  10/10
Story      10/10
Legitness 1000/10

I highly recomment this game to any old school Wolfenstein fan or any new commer. ( I have yet to play New World Order) Thats next for me.
Overall can't beat the price for such a well put together game.
I honestly did Nazi this comming did Jew?

Have fun and slaughter as many filithy pigs as you can!"

reviewText:
The Old Blood is a standalone prequel expansion to The New Order and it is half the length.

Right off the bat, if you played TNO already it has that familiar feel while introducing a new mechanic. You now can use a pipe to take down enemies, climb walls and open hatches. That's pretty much the only new addition in terms of gameplay - everything else is pretty similar. The weapons you get are mainly the old versions of your set in TNO, so there are no dual fires, which makes sense. You do get some new weapons like the Kampfpistol - a single-fire pistol with a grenade projectile, Bombenschuss - sniper rifle, and Schockhammer - shotgun. All enemies encountered in TNO are currently in their prototype stages here, which is also cool to compare.

The game again gives you the choice to play through the chapters stealthily or balls to the walls, however it does highly encourage stealth gameplay. It's all in how you want to play, though, so don't let the stealth-themed introduction throw you off. It contains eight chapters and five difficulty levels. Plenty of perks to aquire that add to the replayability.

If you enjoyed any other previous Wolfenstein title, it's a must-buy.

Personal Rating: 9/10

reviewText: Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is one hell of an interesting expansion to its core game, The New Order. For those of you wondering, despite being a standalone game, The Old Blood does lead directly into The New Order, and given the oppurtunity I would absolutely recommend playing through The Old Blood first.\n\nThe Old Blood is an 8 chapter expansion that is suprisingly lengthy. My first playthrough took around 8 hours total to beat, though my second run took about half that time. During development, MachineGames took two individual ideas they had for expansion content, and combined them into one, giving us the two parts of The Old Blood: Rudi Jager and The Den of Wolves" and "The Dark Secrets of Helga Von Schabbs". The first part is by far the more standard of the two
date: whilst the second part veers into the occult elements that were amiss in The New Order for the most part.\n\nGameplay-wise
recommended: you're getting pretty much the exact same core mechanics
hoursPlayed: expect with a technical downgrade. As the game takes place 10 years prior to The New Order
voteText: BJ Blazkowicz has a significantly more aged arsenal to utilize. Thankfully
helpfulPercent: it's pretty much just as effective
votesHelpful: and features some interesting additions such as a bolt-action sniper rifle
votesTotal: a grenade pistol
votesFunny: and optional dual-wielded pipes. Combat is arguably tougher then The New Order
commentsCount: as BJ is more restricted in how effectively he can tackle opponents
column16: though it's still as fluid and enjoyable as it was in The New Order.\n\nThe Old Blood suffers most in the story and visual design elements. Don't get me wrong
column17: the game looks fantastic and provides a number of beautiful vistas that double as challenging levels
column18: however the level of environmental storytelling has decreased significantly. As has the effectiveness of the story. If The New Order told a fantastic story
column19: The Old Blood tells one with similiar ambitions
column20: but it's restricted in its length. Characters here still possess a similiar amount of notable traits and witty and passionate dialogue
column21: the problem is there really isn't enough in it to truly engage the player. I only found the game getting particularly heavy at the very end
column22: during the transition into The New Order.\n\nDespite it's somewhat crammed and less effective story however
column23: I still recommend it as a precursor to The New Order. The combat and overall flow of the game is excellent
column24: and very reasonably priced for several hours worth of content. If you enjoyed The New Order
column25: you'll likely just as much enjoy what's on offer here."

reviewText:
Caution: Contains Wolfenstein: The New Order spoilers... So if you haven't played Wolfenstein: The New Order I suggest you play it first (YOU WILL NOT BE DISAPOINTED) and then come back to The Old Blood!

If you happen to look in my library you will not see Wolfenstein: The New Order... That is because I played it on my PS4. When W:TNO was released I was in the middle of reparing/uprading my gaming rig. Wolfenstein: The New Order looked so promising thast I bought it for my PS4... I wasn't in the least bit dissapointed as Wolfenstein: The New Order ended up being one of my all-time favorite games that I have ever played (sorry PC only people, but W:TNO looked pretty damn good on the PS4)... FPS or any other genre. The voice acting, graphics, level design, in-debth campaign, available weapons, character perks and everything else about the game are extremely incredible in every way! The character creation is so good that I can easily believe that every character that is in the game is a genuinely real-to-life person... Some of which I grew to care deeply about durring the course of the game. The devs doing this ables me to obsess over achieving victory and gives me a clear sense of urgency and what I am fighting for unlike any game that I ahve ever played. W:TNO gives me a sense of immersion unlike any other game I have ever played which is unbelievable for a FPS! The total experience and success that Wolfenstein: The New Order gave me is exactly why I bought Wolfenstein: The Old Blood!

It is extremely ashame that I am just now playing Wolfenstein: The Old Blood as I have had it in my library for a very long time now... For some very strange reason the game would not play on my rig. Well it played but not very well. I decided to wait a couple of months and then give the game another go around. Sure enough the game now plays up to standards and I can now reclaim the immersion that I experienced in W:TNO Although I have only polayed the game for about 4 hours I already know that I am gonna experience the same debth of immersion and feeling that I had with W:TNO. How do I know? Because I just do... It feels the same and plays the same and gives me that same sense of urgency to achieve victory. With new weapons, new and stranger enimies and new levels and enviornments I know that this game is gonna be great and I am gonna get my moneys worth and more!

If you played Wolfenstein: The New Order and totally loved every heartbreaking minute of it (heartbreaking because the ending was a tear jerker) you will definitely  enjoy Wolfenstein: The Old Blood. The only thing bad about the game is that you already know the fate of the hero... But although he dies, he dies for one helluva cause!

reviewText:
I feel conflicted writing about this game. On one hand, it is a mostly  enjoyable experience but on the other it's tough to justify its existence. Wolfenstein: The Old Blood is a major step back in every way from The New Order. It manages to be more linear, have less engaging combat, seemingly only has 4 or 5 different enemies & pointless stealth. You can run past every fight without a second thought. In fact, I managed to just run by several massive fights without an issue.

That being said, the guns feel great and the environments are so well designed that I found myself stopping just to observe and gawk at the scenery around me. The Old Blood is a very beautiful game. The game itself is also over before it truly begins. I managed to finish the game in around 3 and a half hours on normal difficulty (Bring it On). I guess that's to be expected for a $20 title but even so, it still felt way too short. Another major problem is that the final 2 chapters felt incredibly forced and underdeveloped. They seemed so out of place considering how the first 6 chapters and The New Order were handled. It left a bit of a sour taste in my mouth.

I'm stuck between giving this game a thumbs up or a thumbs down. On one hand, I just listed a ton of problems I had with it but on the other I can't say that I had a terrible time either. I feel like if you want a very basic linear shooter that maintains the weapons and mechanics of The New Order, buy this. You won't get much in terms of lore & variety but you will get some dual wielded assault rifles & robo dogs. If that's all you're looking for then it does its job well. If you're looking for something even half as good as The New Order then you are in the wrong place.

Overall, it's a decent game. It's just not a good followup to The New Order". Not even in the slightest."

reviewText:
Let me start out by saying this is Not Recommended because it was disappointing, not because it was bad. The action is the same high quality shooting found in New Order and the map design is for the most part pretty decent.

Now, before I get fuhrer into this review let me mention that my biggest gripe with this game was how it was marketed versus how it actually is. The trailer makes it look like a more lighthearted, kampfy experience. In truth, EVERY scene like that is shown in the trailer. All the other scenes and dialogue are the same broody New Order stuff including rehashed set pieces like being grilled by nazis while undercover and a prison break. They even have a pointless Pick who to save" scene that is determined by whether you decide to wander down a left or right corridor with no real indication as to who is down either.

On to the technical stuff that bothered me. I did nazi much imporvement in the weapon diversity. Aside from the Kampfpistol nothing new really comes to the table and the older variants of the New Order gear are not particularly interesting.

Enemies are basically identical to the New Order crew including those obnoxious shotgun heavies. The addition of the zombies really doesn't add much to the game though the way they interact with the power loader is pretty cool. I also want to give a special shout out to the developers for the most uninspired
date: ♥♥♥♥ boss fights I've seen in an FPS for a good while now.\n\nThis game is a decent pickup on sale just because it's a solid shooter in its own right. Would I recommend it for full price? Heil no."

reviewText:
MachineGames is one of my favorite developers, and this game is one of my highlights for 2015.  This game's a brilliant and... er, somewhat brutal... FPS by the people who know this series best.  As a prequel to Wolfenstein: The New Order, this game takes the story blurbs from Wolf3D and turns them into a full 2015 AAA release.  All I can really say about this reimagining is that they flippin' nailed it.

Complete with excellent writing, villain introductions that would make Bond jealous, and gunplay that's a perfect mix of modern and retro, combined with excellent map design and a well-paced storyline, I simply can't recommend this game enough.  At $60 I could even recommend it, yet this game has been priced as a budget title from the start.

The only complaint I can really make is the final boss.  I won't spoil it, but it's a trope from the linear-shooter-fest days I would have rather seen gone, and it will probably take you several attempts to take down a Nintendo-style boss with only one weak point that's constantly moving.  I'm indifferent to it, but it's going to ♥♥♥♥ a lot of people off.

Part of what this game does best is the tie-ins as a prequel.  Aside from the final cutscene, which pretty much leads directly into TNO, most of the story elements tie directly into last year's game, and there are even several reference you can really appreciate if you've played TNO already.  The easter eggs are also great, but it doesn't try to distract you from the game itself.

You're doing yourself a disservice by letting it sit untouched on the store page.  I'm not one for number scales, but if I truly had to this would be a 9/10.  It truly is excellent, one of the best games I've ever played in fact, and there's only so long you can go without giving it a shot yourself.  It loses a bit of steam in Part 2, sure, but it doesn't change the fact that it honors the famous franchise and further settles MachineGames in their place as a trusted developer for id's classics.

reviewText:
It was a great story... excellent up to the end... but that is where it went wrong...   The ending was horribly lame, easy, contrived and lazy to be honest.  They completely steered from the idea the dead were being dug up and witchcraft was being used in evil rituals  like in the original...  This ending sigh...  just made little sense.. and the end boss... was just the end...     How the game ended was untold.. why events occurred like it did... made no sense...  It was a curse" ... meh. Bethasada .. you could have done better!  I wish they stayed with the sorcery witchcraft ending like the original...   this ending was a major let down.

Granted I love Wolfenstein... they went off the deep end at the end of the story...  which I personally did not like...  Graphics and sound... top notch... everything UP to the end... top notch...   Time from when the dead rise in the town to the end...   I just did not like it... I preferred the original storyline...

Oh well...

It is still a great time to be had.. and fun... but if you expect an ending anywhere close to the original

reviewText:
If you enjoyed Wolfenstein: The New Order, then no doubt you will enjoy The Old Blood.

The gunplay feels as amazing as ever and there are good additions to the weapon roster. The writing is humorous and though the campaign lasts around 5 - 6 hours, there are plenty of collectibles and secrets to keep you entertained for a second run. The challenge mode is a bit lackluster as it only contains combat-heavy sections from the campaign itself.

It is more of the same really and I wish they had put in some interesting ideas or mixed things up a bit like what Blood Dragon did to Far Cry 3. The zombies could have been a good addition except for the fact that their screen time was rather short and they posed very little threat to the player.

Nevertheless, The Old Blood gets my recommendation for its still amazing gunplay but I suggest that you wait until its goes on a sale.

แม่ทัพใหญ่และผู้คิดค้นอาวุธให้กับเหล่า nazi แต่เขาทำพลาดเลยถูกจับเป็นนักโทษ เขาเลยต้องหาทางหนีออกมาจากปราสาทwolfenstein ให้ได้
ผมค่อนข้างชอบเนื้อหาของภาคนี้เลยที่เดียว เพราะมันให้อารมณ์เหมือนเกม wolfenstein 3D ที่ให้เราเป็นนักโทษและมีจุดหมายคือหนีออกจากปราสาท wolfenstein ให้ได้ ผมว่าการที่เขาใช้ชื่อว่า
old blood อาจจะเป็นเพราะเขาคงอยากจะพาเรากลับไปเล่นต้นกำเนิดของเเกมนี้ ที่มีเป่าหมายตอนแรกคือหนี แล้วค่อยกลับสังหารตัว deathshead
นอกจากนี้เกมอีกทั้งยังมีการใส่ nazi zombie เข้ามาด้วย มันทำให้ผม นึกถึงภาค Return to Castle Wolfensteinขึ้นมาเลยทีเดียว ที่มีเหล่าทหารโครงกระดูกผีดิบ กับพวกมนุษย์ทดลองต่างๆ ให้อารมณ์หลอนขนลุกเป็นอย่างดี

-บอกเลยว่าใครหลายคนที่ชอบเล่นเกม fps ที่มีระบบ healing factor อาจจะรู้สึกไม่ชินกับเกมนี้เพราะเขา นำระบบเลือดกับเกราะแบบสมัยก่อนกลับมาใช้

-ภาพ : เหมือนภาคเดิม จากภาคแรก

-A.I. : เก่งขึ้นเยอะถ้าเทียบกับภาคแรกถือว่ายิงปืนแม่นมาก

-ข้อเสีย : ผมว่ามันไม่ค่อยต่างอะไรกับภาคแรกเลยอ่ะ รู้สึกเฉยๆมากถ้าเทียบกับการเล่นภาคแรกครั้งแร เหมือนกับว่าเราซื้อเนื้อเรื่องของเกมซีรี่ย์มาเสพเสียมากกว่า พูดอีกแบบคือ มันไม่ค่อยมีอะไรใหม่หรือไม่มีอะไรมากดึงดูดให้เราเล่นจนจบมากนัก บอสในเกมก็เฉยๆไม่ได้ epic อะไรเหมือนภาคแรก
มีฉากหนึ่งให้เราขับหุ่นผ่านด่าน แต่มันไม่อะไรเลยนอกจากทุบ ไม่เหมือนภาคที่แล้ว ที่ให้เราขับหุ่นสู้ยิงปืนสู้กับนาซีอย่างสะใจ อันนี้ให้เราขับบวกกับใช้ปืนของเราเองยิง(ไม่เข้าใจเหมือนกันว่าจะใส่หุ่นทำไม ปืนที่ตัวหุ่นก็ไม่มี หุ่นมีประโยชน์แค่ทุบประตู)

-สรุป: เกมที่มีระยะเวลาในการเล่นจนจบกลางๆ กับเกมราคา 669 บาท....ผมถือว่าโอนะ ถ้าใครกำลังมองหาเกมมันๆไม่ต้องคิดอะไร ภาพสวยในราคาดี ผมก็ขอแนะนำเลย ถ้าเทียบกับภาคแรกผมว่าเขายังคงรักษาคุณภาพความสนุกเอาไว้ได้ดีอยู่ เกมถือว่าออกไวมากแต่ bugs ก็ไม่ค่อยมีให้เห็นถือว่าทำงานมาดีมาก
ปล.เกมนี้ผมได้มา 336 บาท(pre-order ลดให้ครั้งหนึ่งคุ้มมาก) ถ้าใครอยากเล่นแต่ยังไม่มีตังหรือไม่มั่นใจ ก็รอลดก็ได้ครับ

reviewText:
The Old Blood, is aimed towards both the audience for the old wolfenstein games and The New Order. The gameplay is the same as TNO, except with the addition of a pipe that helps you out throughout. The story, although is lacking compared to TNO is still something worth being a part of, and the challenge is back (I recommend the 2nd hardest difficulty for the most fun).

This time, they also added a few surprises in there (not spoiling). The stealth is much better and more heart slowing-ly stressful.

Overall, I'd have to say that this is absolutely worth the $20-$40 range and a good starter before you get into the next game. However, for some reason, there isn't the comeback and continue the story" feel of TNO. It's more like "Come back and kill more Nazi's".

8/10"

reviewText:
TL:DR felt a lot like RTCW
The only downside of this game were the poor resolution textures, thanks to Tech 5 graphic engine.

This is a very nostalgic game in two ways. First of all, it really reminded me of RTCW, the atmosphere is there and going inside the castle one more time was a wonderful experience. Second, every chapter in the game has a hidden Wolfenstein 3D level....fully playable. Goose bumps?

You will see....just get it. It lasts about 10 hours without rushing the game. Play it on max difficulty. It really felt old school, you can die very easily, especially in the Wolfenstein 3D levels if you are not careful. Yes it felt kind of old school.

You can play this without having played The New Order. It is a prequel and it almost looks like a remake of RTCW (it is not).

The main difference with The New Order is the fact that 10 challenges (shooting challenges with hitpoints, combos etc) are there. If you played Call of Juarez: gunslinger, well the challenges are more or less exactly like the challenges in Gunslinger.

Great, great game.

Pro:
- everything

Con:
- some bad textures due to the not so great graphic engine
