reviewText:
Achtung! In many ways I actually prefer The Old Blood to The New Order.

Everything that was good about The New Order is still here: solid gameplay, good combat, nazi killing fun, and enjoyable secret hunting. Quite a fair bit more stealthing sections than before, and they're better all around, which I consider a plus since I found the stealth sections in The New Order too short, and many of them largely inconsequential. Shooting your way through them is, of course, an obvious option as before (and required to get high scores in the one or two that return as combat challenges), but I appreciate the attention that has been given to the stealth sections.

It's a good deal shorter than the New Order, even if you spend time secret hunting, but for once the story is a coherent narrative - rather than just individual, albeit cool, set piece levels without any rhyme or reason. It pays considerable homage - and is essentially a remake of - the first quarter or so of Return to Castle Wolfenstein, but the supposed supernatural is connected to the super science elements of The New Order: most people miss this though, since it's only confirmed in a few places (the letter in Helga's room at the tavern, for one).

Sure, nazi zombies as a game concept is scraping the bottom of the creativity barrel these days, but they're visually interesting - if not especially exciting to fight, without some live nazis to confuse the action thrown into the mix. Sometimes there are some live nazis as well for a good three-way fight, but the levels where you mainly find zom-zoms are 90% them and only a few live nazis. If nazi zombies is not your cup of tea, super science explanation or no, then stick with The New Order. The end boss isn't anything to write much home about, although I do love the Lovecraftian vibe - and, again, nothing much explicitly supernatural going on here, it's a man made construct though a lot more harder to swallow than the 10th century gas and the undead. Overall, I liked it all, but your mileage may vary.

I preferred the combat challenge maps, the quick ability to replay those specific sections, and the scoring system therein that The Old Blood has to the game modes that the enigmas could unlock in The New Order. The weapons are largely the same as in the 1946 prologue of The New Order (obviously), with a few new ones thrown in - the pipe and Kampfpistole I find thematically interesting. The addition of the entire first episode of Wolfenstein 3D I loved, although the conversion does have certain lacks (the AI there can't open doors for some reason?!) - most noticeably how pitifully weak Hans is; still, enjoyable retro stuff if you're into it or for the nostalgia goggles (like me).

tl;dr: Liked The New Order and nazi zombies aren't a deal breaker for you? Buy it.

reviewText:
Love killing Nazis, but you can play through New Order blindfolded? then this is for you, and every fan of gruesome Nazi extermination.

There is not much difference between The Old Blood and The New Order. Some new weapons, yes, but they don't change the gameplay or the tactics.
Visuals and gameplay are just as awesome as in The New Order.
In short this is a prequel well worth $20 where
1.	Everyone can kill more Nazis
2.	Wolfenstein series fans will get an insight on what happened before the Return to Castle Wolfenstein
3.	Drummers can play on Nazi skulls using a pipe
4.	And kill even more Nazis and Nazi zombies

The only negative aspect of the game is the really easy stealth part of it. Playing on I AM DEATH INCARNATE!" difficulty level I only had trouble in 2-3 segments of the game.

Overall mark 8/10

reviewText:
Great game for the value. If you liked New Order, it's more of the same. If you're new to the series, this is a great sampler to whet your appetite for the full title. Even better, it's a prequel. Old Blood ends right before the intro of New Order, so if you like it, you can pick up the full game and continue the storyline without skipping a beat.

Gameplay is a good mix of arcade shooting with grindhouse sensibility and some modern innovations. You can be a ghost and go through the map undetected with stabby stabby and shooting from cover with silenced weapons, or you can go in with blazing akimbo shotguns and rocket launchers. The transition between carnage and caution is seamless. There's something here for every kind of FPS gamer.

Plus, like New Order, this game is surprisingly poignant. Old Blood is only a third of the length of New Order. It took me 12 hours to finish on the hardest difficulty with all ability upgrades and collectibles. However, you may find yourself caring about the characters despite only spending a few moments with them.

If you're already a seasoned vet of New Order, there are some cool new mechanics to interest you. You also get more Wolfenstein which is certainly nice. If you wanted to try New Order but the price tag was too much, Old Blood is a nice way to get a sampling for what's in store for you.

Great way to spend a weekend.

reviewText: A very solid entry into the new" Wolfenstein series.  If you liked The New Order
date: you'll surely enjoy this.  The story and characters don't feel as tight or personal this time around
recommended:
but they are still well done and all the voice acting is great.  A few new weapons help keep the combat fun and interesting to play with.  I had a lot of nostalgic moments both from the games "retelling" of the events inside the castle as well as the nightmare levels from Wolf 3D.  This game touches on a lot of story points from Return to Castle Wolfenstein in a much shorter game.  I played on the 2nd hardest difficulty and felt it was a good challenge.  I would recommend this to fans of all shooters as well as those wanting more of TNO style gameplay until Machinegames (hopefully) comes out with the next entry.

A few notes:
-Game ran perfect (never below 60fps) maxed out on my mid-high range system with a GTX780.
-Stealth or Rambo

reviewText:
I initially posted a glowing review, but after playing through a bit more I have to revise it a bit. There are some improvements over The New Order, namely, no more unskippable intros before levels, and no more annoying quests like finding someone's toys or running similar errands. Gameplay is fun, just like in TNO.

However.

The graphics have taken a giant step backward. W:TNO has much better graphics and runs perfectly smoothly on my system (4770K/GTX 680/16GB), without any texture pop-in. The graphics in W:TOB are significantly inferior (which would be understandable if there were a lot of complaints about the system requirements for TNO). The strange thing, however, is that now the texture pop-in is horrendous. It's really, really bad. I launched TNO just to see if it was a driver issue, but that still runs perfectly. I'm not the only one having texture pop-in problems, so something has gone very wrong in the QA department.

Another complaint I have is that the developers have removed the open, extensible nature of the engine, which is a large part of what made id games so much fun. I would have loved the ability to mod weapons, enemies, etc. But the console is artificially restricted - you can't change the values of cvars easily, i.e. you can't do set cvarname value. This makes no sense, because you can still do cvaradd cvarname value to change cvar values. I don't get the point of this.

I still recommend this game, because it's still leagues ahead of most single-player FPS games today. But I really hope they fix the graphics glitches in the next installment, and make the game more open to modding. Modding is what keeps a game alive, long after people have grown bored of the vanilla version.Why would you not want that?
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Old Blood is my perfect game.

It is paced perfectly. You never get bored as the stealth/massacre/exploration/gag elements of gameplay are being constantly rotated. And it's possible to complete the story in about 7 hours at one breathtaking sitting.

The graphics are probably the same, but the game is way better optimized: no weird glitches or bugs. Even the infamous textures problem of the New Order is mostly fixed (it still surfaces from time to time, but it's nowhere as annoying).

The atmosphere of grotesque and dark yet somewhat funny alternative history permeates everything: it's in the brooding gray architecture, steely character design, theatrical antagonists, and NPC dialogues. The attention to detail is stunning, everything from posters to cigarette packs to historical artifacts contributes to this unique balance of grim and humorous.

All in all, it is the perfect tongue-in-cheek epic bloodbath, reminiscent of the games of old.

We definitely need more games like that.

reviewText: Overall a great game and I highly recommend. One of the few games in recent memory I've played all the way through. Only have a few complaints. The stealth sections. Hate them. The whole stealth aspect feels forced in these types of games and not sure why developers feel obligated to include it in every game nowadays. Would rather it have been left out completely. I don't buy Wolfenstein games to crawl around and hide behind boxes just to throw a puny knife at my enemies. Give me shotguns and rocket launchers and mayhem please! To be fair, there is plenty of run and gunning. There are only a few sections where you really have to stealth. Also as others have mentioned there are a ton of items to be picked up in this game, unfortunately you have to press E" to pick up every single one of them. Should have just automatically picked up the ammo for you at least. Other then that though the game looks and plays great. Well worth the price."

reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order was one of the best games I played last year. It’s rich world, over-the-top style and fast-paced gunplay was second to none in a way shooters haven’t been in a while and with the lack of a sequel in sight, Wolfenstein: Old Blood is there to remind us why MachineGames made killing Nazis feel new.

The story takes place months before the events of New Order in two parts, with returning protagonist BJ Blazkowicz infiltrating a rebuilt Castle Wolfenstein to obtain the location of General Deathshead’s base. Though told in two parts, the story isn’t necessarily a tale of concurrent events, but is progressed through in a linear fashion. Old Blood’s story is pretty solid and while its five hour length doesn’t exactly lend itself well to the character development and pre-mission interactions in The New Order, it’s made up for in good dialogue between characters, as well as call-backs to other titles in the series and the excellent monologues that the main character delivers. Blazkowicz himself is again in the habit of talking to himself, but more about the things that remind him of his home and family, giving a closer look at how Blazkowicz possibly deals with the atrocities he witnesses and inflicts on Nazi forces.


Despite Old Blood being a smaller game, its scope is huge for a downloadable. The game is chock full of set-pieces, but does a good job of balancing player agency within the set-pieces themselves. There’s a huge variety of environments that allow you to explore different pathways, coupled a huge amount of collectibles, in-game lore to read and more stealth or combat choice sequences. The issue with these sections performed in stealth is something I feel New Order suffered from; it’s too simple, therefore too boring. It again feels like a tacked-on option for players who want to choose a sneaky approach, but there isn’t enough depth to the stealth for it to feel satisfying. There are no vision cones, the AI is too docile to be any kind of challenge, nor is there great enough of a reward versus taking things loud for it to be anything more than it to feel like a last-minute addition, especially in certain sections where it becomes flat out repetitive and dull. Other than that, the combat still feels slick like its predecessor as well as inventive with new mechanics like using your new best friends; the pipes, to scale walls to get better vantage points and the ability take down bigger enemies without the need for bigger guns. I think overall the new mechanics don’t necessarily improve the game in any meaningful way, but are still adequate for what they try to do.

The weapons in Old Blood are a somewhat mixed bag, especially if you’re someone coming  from The New Order. Returning weapons like the assault rifle still feel great to shoot, but the new-old weapons feel exactly what they are – Old. Being weapons from the 40s rather than the 60s, they feel obviously inferior to the ones featured in the original game in retrospect, but do the job fine in this prequel setting. To name a few examples, the sniper slash assault weapon in New Order is replaced with a jacked up Kar98k, the rocket launcher assault rifle attachment is replaced with a pistol version of a grenade launcher and the double barrel shotgun from the intro of New Order is featured and at one point turned into a sawn-off, reducing its range. None of the new weapons offer anything besides the feeling of using old-school armaments and I feel like there could have been a bit more invention in creating something that only would have worked in the Occult-adoring confines of Castle Wolfenstein.

On the subject of the Occult, Old Blood introduces a new enemy that has shambled its way back from 2001’s Return to Castle Wolfenstein; Zombies. While they have been covered in the series before, this time zombies can come from simply killing a living Nazi soldier. It allows you to try and turn attention away from you to get in a quick shot at bigger enemies by turning a guy in the middle of a squad, but doesn’t last too long. As the story progresses, you’re forced to fight bigger waves of undead in tighter environments, but it becomes less of a challenge and more of a chore to keep pulling the trigger as you pretty much walk through small hordes using headshots or cut through them with shotguns.

Criticisms aside, Wolfenstein: Old Blood is still a fine game, especially a fine downloadable. It doesn't really set out to reinvent the wheel, but being a smaller title for the price point, it’s certainly more than serviceable. I thoroughly enjoyed it, as The New Order fans probably will. For newcomers, this is definitely a slice of the new Wolfenstein experience you could use as a great jumping off point; just expect the tone to be a little less spooky when you start The New Order. Bottom line, if you’re looking for more Wolfenstein - this is more Wolfenstein. And that’s fine with me. I give Wolfenstein: Old Blood a 3/5.

reviewText:
I'll update the review as I go - currently clocked: 6 hours (complete).

80 min - This game feels less 'New Order' and more Metro Last Light where I am now. While clearly different games, the atmosphere of terror (especially on the hardest difficulty) and the emphasis on stealth gameplay is very similar. I'm absolutely loving it.

Old Blood performs incredibly well on my high-end rig and feels like something fresh (as an expandalone) to a game I already loved! Fantastic so far. So much content for such little cost, and I know pricing reviews are useless, but I am impressed for the content / cost ratio right now.

105 min - some stuttering experienced, which should not be happening. Otherwise, game continues to fascinate with great environments and slick gameplay.

3 hours - the only thing I have left to comment on is the stellar sound design. Especially obvious during stealth, boards creak, boots thud and soft, creepy music lurks in the background. Use headphones for this one, it sounds amazing.

6 hours (finished) - what an incredible feeling this is. An emotional, serene ending to an incredible game. Stuttering seemed unique to chapter 3, which featured some odd level design. All 7 other chapters were incredible, with gorgeous visuals, amazing characters and disturbing music. A must-play for any shooter fan. An easy purchase.

reviewText: Overall a great game and I highly recommend. One of the few games in recent memory I've played all the way through. Only have a few complaints. The stealth sections. Hate them. reviewText:
Wolfenstein: The New Order was one of the best games I played last year. It’s rich world, over-the-top style and fast-paced gunplay was second to none in a way shooters haven’t been in a while and with the lack of a sequel in sight, Wolfenstein: Old Blood is there to remind us why MachineGames made killing Nazis feel new.

The story takes place months before the events of New Order in two parts, with returning protagonist BJ Blazkowicz infiltrating a rebuilt Castle Wolfenstein to obtain the location of General Deathshead’s base. Though told in two parts, the story isn’t necessarily a tale of concurrent events, but is progressed through in a linear fashion. Old Blood’s story is pretty solid and while its five hour length doesn’t exactly lend itself well to the character development and pre-mission interactions in The New Order, it’s made up for in good dialogue between characters, as well as call-backs to other titles in the series and the excellent monologues that the main character delivers. Blazkowicz himself is again in the habit of talking to himself, but more about the things that remind him of his home and family, giving a closer look at how Blazkowicz possibly deals with the atrocities he witnesses and inflicts on Nazi forces.


Despite Old Blood being a smaller game, its scope is huge for a downloadable. The game is chock full of set-pieces, but does a good job of balancing player agency within the set-pieces themselves. There’s a huge variety of environments that allow you to explore different pathways, coupled a huge amount of collectibles, in-game lore to read and more stealth or combat choice sequences. The issue with these sections performed in stealth is something I feel New Order suffered from; it’s too simple, therefore too boring. It again feels like a tacked-on option for players who want to choose a sneaky approach, but there isn’t enough depth to the stealth for it to feel satisfying. There are no vision cones, the AI is too docile to be any kind of challenge, nor is there great enough of a reward versus taking things loud for it to be anything more than it to feel like a last-minute addition, especially in certain sections where it becomes flat out repetitive and dull. Other than that, the combat still feels slick like its predecessor as well as inventive with new mechanics like using your new best friends; the pipes, to scale walls to get better vantage points and the ability take down bigger enemies without the need for bigger guns. I think overall the new mechanics don’t necessarily improve the game in any meaningful way, but are still adequate for what they try to do.

The weapons in Old Blood are a somewhat mixed bag, especially if you’re someone coming  from The New Order. Returning weapons like the assault rifle still feel great to shoot, but the new-old weapons feel exactly what they are – Old. Being weapons from the 40s rather than the 60s, they feel obviously inferior to the ones featured in the original game in retrospect, but do the job fine in this prequel setting. To name a few examples, the sniper slash assault weapon in New Order is replaced with a jacked up Kar98k, the rocket launcher assault rifle attachment is replaced with a pistol version of a grenade launcher and the double barrel shotgun from the intro of New Order is featured and at one point turned into a sawn-off, reducing its range. None of the new weapons offer anything besides the feeling of using old-school armaments and I feel like there could have been a bit more invention in creating something that only would have worked in the Occult-adoring confines of Castle Wolfenstein.

On the subject of the Occult, Old Blood introduces a new enemy that has shambled its way back from 2001’s Return to Castle Wolfenstein; Zombies. While they have been covered in the series before, this time zombies can come from simply killing a living Nazi soldier. It allows you to try and turn attention away from you to get in a quick shot at bigger enemies by turning a guy in the middle of a squad, but doesn’t last too long. As the story progresses, you’re forced to fight bigger waves of undead in tighter environments, but it becomes less of a challenge and more of a chore to keep pulling the trigger as you pretty much walk through small hordes using headshots or cut through them with shotguns.

Criticisms aside, Wolfenstein: Old Blood is still a fine game, especially a fine downloadable. It doesn't really set out to reinvent the wheel, but being a smaller title for the price point, it’s certainly more than serviceable. I thoroughly enjoyed it, as The New Order fans probably will. For newcomers, this is definitely a slice of the new Wolfenstein experience you could use as a great jumping off point; just expect the tone to be a little less spooky when you start The New Order. Bottom line, if you’re looking for more Wolfenstein - this is more Wolfenstein. And that’s fine with me. I give Wolfenstein: Old Blood a 3/5.

reviewText:
Short AnswerThe campaign is a measely five-six hours of content IF you really want to find everything and you are decently skilled at first person shooters, the price may or may not be justified for those looking for a complete game. For those who are continuing the franchise, definetly get it but I suggest waiting for a sale. However, it is a game I would recommend anyone to get who enjoys World War II variants and killing Nazis.

Primary Mechanics: Gameplay and AIAfter completing this game over two playthroughs on the hardest difficulty Uber" I can say that the enemy mechanics are much more polished than the predecessor in some regards.
The enemy takes advantage of flanking routes much more often. There would be many times where advancing down one path to root out an enemy defensive emplacement would end up on the other flank quickly relocating to get behind me
date: and in many cases manning defensive guns if they were there or throwing a fury of grenades to cover their comrades. This is a trait I haven't seen in many shooters and actually provides a much needed challenge to the game.\n\nOfficers no longer call in an endless stream of reinforcements and actually have a delay before calling in additional soldaten compared to The New Order where the instant they became alerted to you
recommended: they started raining down fresh soldaten like it was a sales pitch.\n\nEnemy variation is much more mixed on most levels. Where most of the time you would face either only light infantry or heavy infantry
hoursPlayed: now they almost always come in a 2:1 ratio of light to heavy. Heavy shock infantry now seem to tank damage for the light unarmored infantry to advance allowing the entire force to spread over a wide area to pin you down
voteText: again another mechanic I haven't seen in many first person shooters and well done.\n\nMAJOR SPOILER!!!! Zombies have a mixed agro of charging attacks and stumbles unlike most versions where they only have a single form of attack move adding some additional challenge when in close quarters.Another welcome addition is the overall improvement to the stealth feature. While again there are some unreal moments where killing someone/leaving a corpse in front of a patrol and them not even noticing is still there
helpfulPercent: the overall detection of the enemy is much improved making it more of a challenge and forcing a player to always be aware of their every movement.\n\nOne thing I would say I did not appreciate though was only one "new" weapon which takes place of a dual knife
votesHelpful: the pipe. You find this very early in the game and it sticks with you in addition to the game relying heavily on its use. Sure it's a decent weapon and a requirement to complete every mission but for a prequel inside of a GIANT RESEARCH BASE there was a massive lack of new weaponry.\n\nThe perk tree overhaul is different from the last one in some perspectives and not a complete rerinsing which meant some new mechanics were introduced on a fully upgraded player but many of them over very little to the player to use so accomplishing the tasks is often not recommended unless you want the achievements. Compared to the predecessor
votesTotal: the perk tree was a dissapointment because it had no real benefits. Also the grenades are very underpowered and unless you plan on baiting a bunch of enemys to try and melee you
votesFunny: hard to kill three with one grenade.\n\nThere's added humor if you listen to every conversation between each pair of soldaten you meet so I suggest not killing anyone who has a speech line until after they finish. Particularly the two soldaten in the wine cellar
commentsCount:
if you play the game you will thank me for not ruining this moment.

The StorylineThere were many emotional moments added by the developers into this storyline much like in The New Order which were well done. I won't list them for spoiler reasons but those of you who have played the game would probably agree that they leave mixed feelings despite being well executed. The overall mission changes slightly and moves smoothly with little to no major setting changes which is nice since it matches the story of being a Castle Wolfenstein game and remaining in Castle Wolfenstein.

For those that never played the pre-sequel
column16:
there is a lot of information and character building that helps you understand events that happen in the seq-prequel in addition to covering up any "oopsies" that might have happened in making a previous timeline from an already compelted one. It also does a nice job of not really spoiling anything if you again didn't play the other title so job well done.

The VerdictDefinetly a must have when on sale and a good challenge for those who like the franchise. There's a lot more fun in using the old flashbacks for the nightmare which is essentially a game in-of-itself.
CategoryScore out of 10Graphics8Storyline9.5Voice-Acting10Difficulty6.5Overall Score8.5-9"

reviewText:
Product received for free

This game delivers pretty much exactly what it promises; no more, no less.

The SetupFührer Adolf Hitler has risen from his 100 year slumber and has begun anew his conquest of Europe, unleashing his unending hordes of Nazi monstrosities upon the free people of the Old World.  Only you, the last of the Blazkowicz bloodline, have the power to wield the holy might of the legendary gun, the Nazi Killer, and with its power you must infiltrate Castle Wolfenstein and put an end to the menace, banishing it for another century.

Or something like that.  Look, there were Nazis and guns, alright?  The game just sort of assumes you know how to combine them the right way.

The GameVery straightforward shooter with a small cast of weapons and enemies.  On your team you've got the usual culprits: Pistol, Shotgun, Machine Gun, etc.  If you're feeling frisky you can really go off the rails with Bolt-Action Rifle.  The enemy will field against you almost exclusively Nazi With Machine Gun but will occasionally throw you off by deploying Armored Nazi With a Shotgun.  In classic Wolfenstein fashion Dog makes an occasional appearance too.  To the game's credit: in the last quarter of it they finally loose something particularly new (to the game, not to the lore or genre), and it's nice.  Environments, at least, get some good variation.

For the most part you proceed room to room to room, and through most rooms you are given the option to either stealth it out or just blast your way through.  Objective markers helpfully direct you to point B to point A along the straight line that is the path you must weave.  There's no need to burden yourself with worry over the usual health/armor/ammo system; turns out in the 1940's they used to build castles not out of bricks and stone but out of medpacks, ammo crates, full suits of kevlar.

So, more or less: everything old is old again.  Not that it's any bad.  The game does nothing poorly.  The situation is exactly as I said in the start: it gives you exactly what it says it's going to and no more (or less).

The SummaryIf you got it for free with DOOM, like I did?  Recommended.  Otherwise, not really recommended unless you are an unquenchable fan of storing your bullets in warm Nazi bodies, have a WWII-themed action hero fetish, or you find a bargin bin discount.

reviewText: If you've played Wolfenstein: The New Order. You know what you're getting into with this game. If you haven't I suggest playing that first but if you decide to jump into this standalone expansion, prepare for solid idTech graphics, punchy guns that feel great tearing through zombies and lots of gibfests with the more powerful weapons in your arsenal. It's mindless fun with excellent shooting and a solid story that you'll want to see through to the end. To say that's it's relatively brief is not in context of others games. You'll easily get 8+ hours of a good time and that's without searching for all the gold collectibles. Which honestly, add nothing to the experience. All in all, you could do worse spending a 10 spot on this and I recommend it to anyone looking for a predictable (gameplay-wise) yet quite fun shooting gallery of Nazis. And let's be honest, everyone's favorite thing to shoot is Nazis.\n\nMy one gripe is that you know when you enter a large room, it turns into an arena of shooting all the bad guys to progress to the next area. Minor but it is a relic of gameplay's past that I'd prefer was more elegantly folded into the flow of the game.

reviewText: Well, what should I say. Old blood is a prequel to wolfenstein new order, that was my favourite fps in years and game of the year of 2014 and I have to say Old Blood satisfied my lust for more nazi blood. The levels are more complex and the enemies are plenty, it's a first person shooter fans dream. The chapters/levels are nice designed and every location is highly detailed. The new guns are fun to use, especially the bombenshuss, which is a step son for sniper rifle in new order and the handy rocket launcher is a total blast to play with, quite literally I might add :) The story is somewhat lackluster when comapred to the original, but it is satisfying enough if you pay attention to the letters and dialogs between various nazi soldiers, especially the grammar nazi :) There are lots of easter eggs hidden in the old blood, the exploration is really well done, there are a ton of collectibles hidden around the chapters and overall it's a complete package. I paid 19.99 euro for it when it was available for preorder and I don't regret it. I loved it so much that I even bought a boxed copy along with a nice set of BJ's dogtags. I finished the game on my first playthrough within almost 10 hours, but that's because I like to explore and search for hidden treasure and enjoy the beauty of this marvelous game.\nI would recommend this game to any fps fan most definitely and without a doubt. Iam off to play the game again to find collectibles I didn't manage to get on my 1st playthough and to earn some achievements and I will also try the new challenges that seem like fun.

reviewText: Not only does the game provide throwbacks to previous Wolfenstein games for the diehard fans, but it's also a fun shooter with great weapons and a very compelling story. If you haven't played The New Order, first, it won't be neccesary to play The New Order in order to understand what's happening in this game. Second, what are you waiting for? Regardless of whether you play The New Order after or before The Old Blood, they are both great games. But a warning: there is a LOT of blood and gore. If it's not your thing, I recommend avoiding it. It is rated R +18 in Australia for a reason! Otherwise, highly recommended.

reviewText:
Return to Castle Wolfennstein, again.

Its both what you do in the game and what it feels like.
Very reminicent of the fist few levels in RtCW
Gameplay is damn good
New guns are pretty good, though its missing the FG42 from RtCW which is a negative for me
(also no thompson like the one in The New Order but with the setting it makes sense, still sux)
I prefer this time period over the alternate 1960s
Levels are pretty damn good, though they feel bare in some ways
Enemies are fun to shoot in the face
Very damn short (4 hours with some secrets invovled though i skipped some of the 3D levels)
story wise this is how TNO should have been, even though I love the story in that one I didnt like the love story nor the extra characters,  they were well written but wolfenstein always felt like it was BJ saving the world alone. This game goes back to that feeling and I loved it. more shooty less feely. though this game feels weird when sticking to the lore of RtCW. (BJ acts like he has never been to the Castle, nor does anyone acnowlege is first escape. Super Soldiers seem downgraded for some reason)

7.5/10 short but a lot like RtCW

PS. Remake RtCW pls and I will stut up about it

reviewText:
Jesus Christ this is a stealth game that's a love letter to pipes, not an actual action game.  You easily get overwhelemed so easily you have to use stealth most of the time and that's just not fun.

Usual way to clear an area

1) Sneak in and get the notifications and indicators of where the commanders are (the guys who call in reenforcements)
2) Sneak around and try to kill them
3) When you fail get up and run to find their exact positions
4) Die because once they summon a non stop stream of guys you're boned
5) Respawn
6) Stealth kill the closest commanders, get up and run headlong towards the remaining commander and kill him
7) He will still summon adds but since alarms magically stop once you kill the commander you should be able to take them

Rinse, repeat. Forever.


If you want an action game with great gun play and big battles and you vs the entire Nazi army head on, this ain't it.

reviewText: I actually bought this before trying The New Order.\nIt is one hell of a cool Fps, one of the best i've been playing in a long while. The plot in this one is kinda similar to Return To Castle Wolfenstein. The game is packed full of easter eggs and nods to other famous games, and it is more lighthearted than New Order, in a good way (plenty of jokes and humour, while retaining its credibility thorughout the whole run. Don't get me wrong, i loved the ♥♥♥♥ out of New Order, this one is just awesome in a different way). The gameplay is solid, the guns look and sound awesome and they really all pack a punch, unlike its predecessor (now the shotgun is actually quite useful, and there's not that bloody boring laser-cutter thingy). The bad guys look as bad as B-movie bad guys should look. The soundtrack is cool and the settings really well made and with loads of details. As everyone says, it's not a very long game but it's well worth its price, and i will recommend it to everyone who loves old school fps games and shooting nazis (and mutant nazis and zombie nazis and dog nazis and so on).

reviewText:
Runs great on my ♥♥♥♥♥♥ hardware, has beautiful vistas, but it gets dull real fast if you have played TNO. You don't even meet the main villain until halfway through the campaign, which wouldn't be that bad if she was intriguing in any way. I think she appears for about 15 minutes of game time, and honestly isn't even that evil, unlike the villains from TNO, whom I actually felt anger towards. The pipe is only used for climbing up walls (very specific walls). You can use it to stealthily take out enemies, but it's honestly easier to run and gun than go in sneakybeaky-like. The final boss has attacks meant for a RPG, as in you have to dodge them. Oh wait, you can't because this is an FPS! I ended up just running around the level taking potshots at him until he died.

Buy The New Order, it's more expensive but better in every way.
3/10

reviewText:
Return to Klaxon Wolfenmaze.

3.5 hours in and I have had enough. At 2 hours in I was googling (game minimised) because I was stuck where to go. That was not for the first time. It took ages to work out where to go. At that point I was feeling dejected and stuck with a game I was not happy with. Then I remembered Steam refunds and checked, to find I had gone past two hours.

I wish I had remembered one negative review I read. Somehow the style of writing and what was said told me to not to buy The Old Blood. I forgot and went ahead in the last sale.

Thus far it is just generic. Nothing interesting has happened. It's mostly been winding tunnels or vent climbs, or corridors. Every meeting of more than one or two enemies is accompanied by klaxons (in my headphones). Arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr arrruuurr.....

Even if it gets better, the overall game is spolied by the first few hours. I say no on this one.

(P.S. I liked The New Order a lot.)

reviewText:
I've expected a lot more from this game. Almost from the first minutes it felt boring and I was hoping that the whole game wont be too long. (because I still wanted to finish it) Nothing wrong with WW II setting but exectuion is what makes this game poor. I bought it on sale for about 3€ and I'm glad I didn't paid more. This game could have been so much better if it was properly made/ported to PC. Horrible performance and FPS drops (during the situations with a lot of ragdolls/bodies) on my rig (i7 4790K 4,7GHz & 980 Ti, 16GB DDR 2400MHz), poor 21:9 display support, very few NVIDIA DSR resolutions to choose from (4K or 6K and nothing in between, really?), playing area was very narrow and some point enemies respawned forver until you run forward just (launched the script) to stop them etc..

I've finished RAGE aswell and this game felt like RAGE's mod.


If you can find this game for a few euros give it a shot if you are into WW II games otherwise I suggest you to play something else.

MEH" out of 10."

reviewText:
I've expected a lot more from this game. Almost from the first minutes it felt boring and I was hoping that the whole game wont be too long. (because I still wanted to finish it) Nothing wrong with WW II setting but exectuion is what makes this game poor. I bought it on sale for about 3€ and I'm glad I didn't paid more. This game could have been so much better if it was properly made/ported to PC. Horrible performance and FPS drops (during the situations with a lot of ragdolls/bodies) on my rig (i7 4790K 4,7GHz & 980 Ti, 16GB DDR 2400MHz), poor 21:9 display support, very few NVIDIA DSR resolutions to choose from (4K or 6K and nothing in between, really?), playing area was very narrow and some point enemies respawned forver until you run forward just (launched the script) to stop them etc..

I've finished RAGE aswell and this game felt like RAGE's mod.


If you can find this game for a few euros give it a shot if you are into WW II games otherwise I suggest you to play something else.

MEH" out of 10."

reviewText:
I loved Wolfenstein: The New Order and I expected to love this game... but I do not! at all! I'm so disapointed...

The amount of headbob and screenshake is too damn high! It's really excessive and combined with the atrocious color scheme (grey, grey green and grey-red and also grey) and the jerky motions makes it very hard to keep track of targets.

The guns feel inaccurate but somehow spraying bullets in the general direction of enemies always yields ungodly amounts of headshot. The kills come too easy to be satisfying.

But that's no worry in the short term because there's a very long starting sequence where you stealth" around giant armored robots while activating switches. It's slow paced and pretty damn boring for quite some time before the action starts.

There's also a new clinbing mechanic where you have to worm your way up specialy marked walls by alternating right click and left click. It's easy

it's slow and it's everywhere. I don't know who thought this would be fun... he was wrong.

reviewText: The Old Blood is a game that I will quickly forget. It's half long as it's predecessor and double boring. The storyline is very weak and almost doesn't make sense. The finale is atrociously pathetic and has nothing to do with the pseudo-story. The sound and music ambient are one of the little things that the devs got right. The graphics ambient is also very good, BUT again they used a crappy graphics engine. I can't avoid talking about the ID Tech 5 engine. A very old graphics engine that has nothing to offer these days compared to many other outstanding ones! The fact that this engine doesn't even support SLi leaves no chance on running this game on full detail with ANY GPU. AA option destroys the framerate as weird as it works (only 30FPS or 60FPS jumps, no middle ones). The developers tried to polish a  little this engine filling the graphics options with a lot of tweaks that can't be used at full, and it almost shines, but it fails and ends ruining the experience. It's a shame they hurried and again used this crappy engine... So why the devs took the work to make an excellent graphic detail on a game that uses this engine and cannot experience it at that detail? I don't know... at least is somewhat cheap...but it doesn't justify the monstrous size of the game!

reviewText:
**MILD SPOILERS**

I just finished the game on über in about 9 hours. I've pre-ordered the game so it cost me less and I would definitely say that it's worth the cost. Here's my mini-review:

Like Wolfenstein: The New Order, The Old Blood merges modern military shooters with old school single player FPS and the result is a glorious FPS gameplay that both feels fresh and nostalgic.

Good:
-More of the same. If you loved TNO, you'll still love this.
-Delves deeper into the occult. Whereas TNO is about Deathshead, this about the SS Paranormal Division last seen in Return to Castle Wolfenstein.
-Oh, if you love RtCW, have recently played it, or just remember it fondly, you will LOVE THIS. I won't spoil anything though.
-There's a minor branch in the story that's integrated seamlessly into the gameplay, so that's kinda cool

Bad:
-Not enough character development this time around. However there are still memorable characters around
-ENDED TOO SOON!

Verdict
If you love TNO, or looking to buy TNO but want a taste of what it's about first, get this!
voteText: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Do not be mistaken. There is nothing, absolutely no content of this game that would make it qualify as an 'old school fps'. This is a forced stealth section, regenerating health, cover based, corridor crawling, perk system, trinket collecting, sequence pattern bosses, bosses with constantly respawning mobs, quick time events, full of zombies, meaningless choice system having modern fps. This game is up to it's eyeballs in every bad modern fps idea and even worse most of these bad ideas have been executed better in cheaper products.

The Blood Dragon expandalone was at least funny. There is no humor in this, it's dryly written and performed by a disinterested cast. And it's 6 hours long, not 8. It also has broken multimonitor mouse support and you will want to winlogo+P and run the game on a single screen otherwise it will keep minimizing on you.

You can tell this is a rushed product because the pathfinding on enemies is completely broken. When you reposition you will often run into 8-10 Nazis all piled up in a hallway because they can't even navigate the arenas properly. I paid $10 for it and it wasn't worth free. If you want an 'oldschool fps' or a 'throwback fps' go pick up Shadow Warrior, Ziggurat, or Serious Sam instead.

reviewText:
When I first saw the announcement for The Old Blood I naturally got excited, it was promised to be a prequel to The New Order serving to set up the events of that great game.
I loved The New Order to the point where I absolutely gushed over it when I wrote my review for that game, and as it stands it is one of my highest rated reviews. So what did I think of The Old Blood?

It fell flat on its face and failed to deliver.

The game started off really strong, it had all the aspects I loved in The New Order: Great enemy design and distribution, intense and tactical gunplay, decisive combat switching between man-mode and stealth and level designs that actually felt improved with several different routes and hidden secrets. It built up the foundation for a good story, a main villain to target and a secretive project.

The new weapons added were also fun to use, just like in The New Order firing them had a realistic and satisfying weight and feel to them (with the exception of the sniper rifle, that one didn't seem to do it for me) making the gunfighting all the more attractive.
So where did it go wrong?

In the 6th or so chapter, those intense and hardcore technologically advanced Nazis you were fighting? Forget them, the devs decided to brush them aside and bring in something else. Something that seems to be popular these days. Zombies. (Are you f---ing kidding me?)
That isn't even a spoiler, because they're right there on the store page screenshots. I saw that and was hoping in vain they would be in some alternate gamemode. But nope, the stupid things came literally out of nowhere, they aren't even that fun to fight. With the Nazis I had to think my movement patterns through, stick to cover and keep track of their troop movements. With the zombies I just had to stand still and pop them in the head, no matter how many there were I could wipe them all out with a single clip of my assault rifle and I wouldn't even get a scratch. Trading quality of enemies for quantity was a foolish design choice, turning the challenge curve from intense tactical FPS to a child-friendly carnival shooting gallery.
It's not that I have anything against zombies, games like Killing Floor did them right by focusing the game entirely around them while still keeping a focus on challenge curve. In The Old Blood, they were easily the most boring thing to fight through, presenting little to no threat. They would have been at least tolerable if there was any sort of build-up or hinting that the game was going to take this turn, but in the 6th chapter it turns into a far worse game in an instant. Literally, the chapter starts and then there are suddenly zombies, no explanation, just zombies. There were hints in letters throughout the game mentioning something hidden within the mountain, but if anything I would have expected one of those Jewish technology cache plot-devices that were in The New Order, and that would have made sense since it fits with the established world of the game. Instead we get magically reanimated corpses with a few small specks of actual Nazis dotted around from then on out, as if the game is taunting me with what it could have been.

It's from this point on that the game takes a complete nose-dive downwards to an uncontrollable disaster. Even the final boss, if I can take the liberty to say, was underwhelming.

If you've read this far in and you're still considering buying this game, don't read ahead as there may be spoilers for the end boss:

The final boss was terrible. It's a giant, blind monster that looks like it was taken directly out of Dark Souls and operates it's attacks purely on sound, like the Tentacles in Half-Life. The problem is that this thing flat-out sucks, you shoot him once in the weak spot, move to the upper or lower level of the arena to avoid his attack, repeat. Just like the stupid zombies, the boss came out of nowhere and presented little to no challenge. After playing this far in my brain started to go numb from not having to think at all, and that is not what anybody wants with an advertised prequel to the brilliance of The New Order.


In final consideration: The Old Blood was built up with a seemingly solid foundation that not only collapsed, but shattered under the weight of trending themes, tragically so because it started off so good then became frustratingly simple. A shameless, disorderly mess that is best to be avoided by any fans of The New Order.

reviewText:
Eh. After the first 3 hours I'm not really impressed. It suffers from almost every single problem that was present in The New Order; Still no way to turn off Depth of Field or the absurd amounts of glaring from lightsources and most blurs types. Constantly you go through points of no return when you wanted to search area's for collectables or equiptment. No way to manual/quick save to not be locked into the PoNR checkpoints.

It practically opens with a Forced Stealth Section that's a hour long right out the door, being this is a prequel and you learned how to hack/pick locks in the future you don't do any of that, also your cutting laser is also future-tech and not appearing in this game, instead you get the new climbing mechanic is more dull then any mechanic it replaces because never is it anything more then rotating left and right click.

The silly Perk upgrade requirement's are back but there mostly meaningless now, unlike The New Order almost all of them are slight buffs to ammo pickup or health regen so there doesn't seem to be anything huge like the previous game that you need to work for. Also your basically garunteed to get all of them just from playing normally and shooting everyone, since their all rather simple things like kill 200 guys with a mounted gun, well there's a half dozen turrent sections in the first 3 hours alone.

Overall if you played throught The New Order, both sides, and still wanted to play more of the exact same game but with different minigames, then this is for you. If your like me and did a single side and got bored and quit part way through the alternative timeline then your going to get bored here really quickly.

***
Edit 8/10/15:
Another 2 hours later, (because I have nothing better to do.) Still sucks ♥♥♥♥. Still just walking though the same castle, with the same weapons, doing turret sections fighting the exact same 3 guards types for the last 4 straight hours.

There is still no exciting locations, Moonbase? London? Underwater jew... lab thing?... ♥♥♥♥ all that, you get none of that, you got boring ♥♥♥ stone nazi castle for the entire thing.

What about the cool robot dogs, the 10 story high tripods, sharks with laser beams attached to their heads? Nope, 3 types of guards, and a drone I seen twice in a cutscene that shot a plot device at me.

Overall after these 4 hours I feel this Pipe you find in a sewer prison is the real hero of the story, cuz BJ does every ♥♥♥♥ing thing with this pipe. He climbs with it, he plot device gets out of boss fights with it, opens doors and hatches with it, stealth kills with, it's honestly pretty ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. If Nazi's had these pipes, why the ♥♥♥♥ would they need to make anything else, the world would fall to these things.

Overall game remains ♥♥♥♥. God help me because I'm still atleast 3 hours from the end and I just want the credits to roll so I can delete this piece of ♥♥♥♥ and atleast say I beat it.

***

Edit 8/11/15

Beat it, Of the 8 chapters this game has the only somewhat interesting ones are the last 2. Because their the only 2 not in the same boring ♥♥♥ castle. The end boss was also a joke. Thank god its done, deleted. 3/10.

reviewText:
Much, much worse than New Order.
- Way too linear: you're literally locked in a small room or a corridor most of the time.
- Terrible AI, totally incapable of flanking (in contrast to New Order's, which always tried to surprise the player).
- Awful port: my rig with SLI of GTX 970 can run GTA5 at 4K, but in Old Blood I have to settle for 1920x1080 to get 60 FPS. Oh, and that low-res texture popping from RAGE? It's omnipresent.
- Devs even managed to make zombies boing. Remember those horrors from Return to Castle Wolfenstein (2001) that soaked up your bullets? Yeah, here you can kill them with a single headshot. They're so helpful, they even carry spare ammunition for you in their pockets.
- And, of course, B.J. keeps acting like an idiot.

There's only one thing this game gets right: using the single-shot grenade launcher IS fun. Otherwise Bad Blood is a complete waste of time and money.

reviewText:
-Duration: only 4-5 hours, even when I played through it real slow
-Gameplay mechanics: very clumsy, a downgrade from TNO
-Visuals/performance: Look overall the same, but performance is much worse. Can't even hold 60 FPS (which I gotta mention is the LIMIT, being a huge letdown for anyone with a 120/144hz monitor). Often dipping below 40 FPS for no apparent reason, but at full GPU usage on an overclocked GTX 980. Not even running max settings, very far from it actually. YOU NEED A MONSTER GRAPHICS CARD FOR THIS GAME. And don't get me started on the damn field of view. It HAS a slider that ranges from 80 to 100. Sounds good, right? Except it's not TRUE FOV, even at 100 it barely feels like 70-ish, and lowering it to 80 makes it feel like 50 at best. Nausea and disorientation inducing to the max.

-Story: very boring and doesn't even feel like Wolfenstein. TNO had a properly immersive and suspenseful story, where the other characters actually felt like they mattered. TOB is just a joke.
-Level design: very linear with no exploration or alternate routes to play your own way. The game holds not only your hand, but ♥♥♥♥ing chains you onto the path it wants you to take.

At this point I'm wondering why it's even called Wolfenstein. It's got a few fun moments of nazi killing, but not in the style that defines Wolfenstein. Every enemy now apart from the regular grunts are weird and all have their own bizarre weak spots. They're only difficult once you (quickly) learn how to exploit them, and from there on it's the same boring and tedious task over and over again.

I bought this game because I enjoyed TNO, but this iteration is just an insult to the Wolfenstein franchise. I guess the only silver lining is the low price, and surely you can't expect a big chunk of content at such a low price, but even for the experience of a prequel story this really didn't fill in any blanks or put the story of TNO under a new perspective.

Skip this game, and play The New Order instead.

reviewText:
Very strange how this must have been developed, because it is mostly new content (and a bit better too), at six hours, which is how long The New Order was, but at a third of the price.

Also curious is how it wasn't marketed as a remake of Return to Castle Wolfenstein, because that is exactly what it is. At least, it's the first third of that game, padded out to six hours, with later game stuff like supersoldiers thrown in anyway. You start by infiltrating Castle Wolfenstein, then you get captured, your buddy gets killed, and you make your escape. After a trip down cable cars, you make it to a village where a friend puts you on an underground railroad to find totally not Helga von Bulow and her documents. She finds you out and casts zombies on the place, but you follow her to some catacombs where she summons a monster that kills her and tries to kill you.

The main difference, aside from the obvious omissions after that, is that it's designed the same way The New Order was designed (except for cutscenes, which are rare). Lifeless segmented hallway levels for consoles, along with the occasional big room where a bunch of bad guys patrol and their commanders call in reinforcements. It's padded out to six hours by a lot of repeated setpieces, like fending off an attack on a building or crappy but really easy stealth against supersoldiers. There are also plenty of scenes where a Nazi has you cornered and twirls his or her moustache for a few moments to show that Nazis are evil and all that...

Uber difficulty is slightly more challenging than in the previous game, but still pretty easy. Mostly I died because I didn't bother trying too hard or didn't play the way the game wanted me to. Other times are really hard to shoot through, but they're doable with some really stupid stealth exploits.

They've slightly improved the base game, but not by much. Just play Return to Castle Wolfenstein instead.

reviewText:
Product received for free

It's a good thing I got this game for free, because I think I'd hate myself even more if I were to have bought it. Thankfully, I didn't buy it when it first game out. First off, this game is basically the new Doom game for the modern casual, with a different setting and modern, generic, fps mechanics. This may be good news to some, but for me and people like me, it would probably make you suicidal. Also, it suffers from the same bug the new Doom game suffers from, the ability to not unbind pre-binded key bindings. On top of this, I find it funny how it gives you several advanced graphical & texture settings for textures that are no better than an old Call of Duty game. What the hell is the point of that? Huge guns are silent, melee kills are louder than said huge guns, but are still silent to enemy AI for some reason, character models are copied and pasted and I just couldn't play this game anymore because of all these reasons.

I expected this game to be bad and generic and it was, but I did not expect Bethesda to carry out the traditions of The Old Blood and games like The Old Blood, to the new Doom game, for the new Doom game has very similar menus and interface, some of the same bugs, etc.

If this game did anything for me, it was allowing me to remember how poopy Bethesda currently is as a company. And no, Fallout 4 isn't that great either.

Overall Rating: 3/10

reviewText:
It's more Wolfenstein! What's not to love?

If you enjoyed The New Order, you'll enjoy this. It's more shooty/stealthy action set in beautiful locations (though this time just before the start of TNO, with a familiar return to Castle Wolfenstein and the Ghostapo/Paranormal elements of the previous games). Same BJ charm, inner monologue, and focus on story that really brought TNO to the next level.

It took nearly seven hours on medium difficulty to get all the way through and that's without 100% completion. Well worth it in my opinion. For twenty bucks, this is an awesome expansion pack, and makes me wish more games did them these days instead of DLC offerings.

reviewText: A decent game and addition to the Wolfenstein collection. It has some subtle throwbacks to RtCW (killing commanders before they sound alarms, optional stealth play style, a level about a dig site) and some not-at-all-subtle throwbacks to original Wolfenstein. As a huge fan of RtCW, I wasn't too disappointed, but the game has its flaws.\nSound quality is medocre, with often good tension music and good voice acting, but almost nothing else in terms of ambient effects and gun sounds. The gunplay is passable, with clever enemies to keep it interesting. They will use cover and throw grenades at you at the right time (although not before holding it in the air and yelling to the world about what they're about to do). It's fun to solve literally every obstacle BJ encounters with his lead pipe.\nAlas, the game is short. Don't pay too much for it - it's a standalone DLC prequel to New Order.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Since Wolfenstein: The New Order concludes in such a way as to be open to a sequel, and as its campaign accounts for BJ's whereabouts the entire time, only two options were available to Bethesda and Machine Games: either an entire spin-off with a different lead character taking place whenever they wanted, or a prequel starring BJ. They went with the latter, and aside from the issue of knowing everything would end okay for the hero, as is always an issue with prequels, this game was quite good. Unless they do make a spinoff, we won't know if this was the better choice, but I'm glad they made this game. That said, it just felt inferior to WTNO in most ways: the story above all else...

The actual storyline itself was just boring and uninteresting. You're sent to get a file with the location of a Nazi general. Obviously you fail a lot to stretch out the runtime of the game, and something supernatural happens very late-game which makes things interesting for a few minutes, then you realize there's not really going to be a legitimate explanation for it, and everything predictable happens. There are only two significant villains and they're fairly forgettable. I can't remember the name of the Nazi woman on WTNO, but I will -never- forget her or the scenes she was in. I would love to see her in another Wolfenstein game as she had a real presence. The WTNO villains weren't extremely deep, but they worked well, while WTOB villains were just disappointing.

WTNO takes place in an alternate history 1960, with a significant number of characters who have dialog between missions and you really develop a relationship" with them
date: to the best of a not-that-long first person shooter's ability. In WTOB
hoursPlayed: you never really feel like you knew a character long enough to care that they died. I cared when characters died in WTNO; not heartbroken
voteText: but it was sad or got a reaction out of me. In WTOB
helpfulPercent: someone dies and you're just like "Meh
votesHelpful: okay." There's another "choose who dies" option in this game
votesTotal: very near its end
votesFunny: and it's rather irrelevant and actually difficult to tell which character you are trying to save. You go left to save one and right to save the other
commentsCount: and the game does not tell you which way is for which character! I had read someone else's review and knew to expect this BS
column16: so when I heard "I need to save them
column17:
I looked up a walkthrough to find out which way to go to save the character I wanted to live. I'd recommend you do this as well. Randomly saving one character over the other isn't player choice; it's bad game design.

The setting is another point of inferiority vs WTNO. Alternate history 1960 is a lot more interesting than alternate history 1946. 1946 was a good starting point for WTNO to give you a feel for what's going on, introduct characters, and set up the plot, but they quickly put you into 1960 as it's so much more fun and engrossing. WTNO took a WWII shooter and turned it on its head by moving ahead with this alternate timeline, making story actually a thing of relevance, while WTOB just sits on its hands by taking place in a year nothing -really- interesting is going to happen concerning the overall war effort.

You've probably noticed that I have almost exclusively said negative comments about this game thus far. However, the truth of the matter is that everything I just discussed is executed better the average game. It's all just awful -compared- to WTNO, which raised the bar so high that this game was set up to underwhelm right out of the gate. Of course, the average game" is a steaming pile. The actual number of good games in existence is a tiny fraction of the mass of stinkers out there. The story and setting of this game are just "okay" and too cliche at times. Why then
column18: do I recommend this game? It's all about the gameplay.\n\nWTNO was a great game because it had a story and characters presented very well with combat and stealth that gave interactivity to an interesting plot. The action/shooting and stealth in WTNO was its own reward

column22: and without considerable grinding I'd consider it unlikely for you to get it before the end of your first play through. The only new weapon I enjoyed entirely was the bolt-action rifle
column23: which you can choose to use either a scope or iron sights on
column24: it's hard to deny old school bolt-action fighting is fun
column25: of course unlike TNO's semiautomatic marksman rifle this one cannot be dual wielded.\nThe collectibles and the nightmares also make a return from The New Order
column26: however again these feel like they could've been a bit better
column27: collectibles are now relegated to nothing but gold and silver bars
column29: while expanded on greatly to the point where there's now one in every chapter
column31: something I would like to attribute at least in part to the old level designs clashing somewhat with the new mechanics (mainly how slowly you move in such large mazes
column32: making exploration and backtracking more tedious than they needed to or should be). The New Order was the first game in a very long time that I was compelled to 100%
column33: a compulsion that I couldn't get from this game.\nFor the most part the enemies are the same variety you got used to in TNO
column34: with a few changes here and there. Supersoldiers now have an exposed weakpoint
column35: the normal ones can have their power generators targeted to knock them down
column36: allowing you to pull open their armor
column37: which enables you to take them down much faster
column38: while the tethered version (which are only seen in one or two levels
column39: both in stealth segments) can be killed by either disabling their external generator and then cutting their wires
column40: or simply shooting their wires if you have a gun to shoot with. You also have the occasional encounter with flying combat drones
column41: which unlike the machine gunning ones seen in the previous game now sport rocket launchers and much larger hulls.\nStory-wise The Old Blood takes a different Direction than The New Order
column42: going back to 1946 with the raid that allowed the allies to launch their suicide assault on Deathshead's compound in the opening level of The New Order. Here you'll instead find yourself in Castle Wolfenstein and the nearby town of Wolfburg fighting the SS occult research division and their experiments. While many were hoping for Wolfenstein to go more into the occult themes
column43: and I did definitely find this game's two main villains entertaining
column44: I would say the story themes felt rather watered down
column45: but this was a gripe I had with The New Order's story themes as well so I may be the odd one out here.\nDespite these nitpicks and gripes though I'd still highly recommend this game because when it gets down to it none of these flaws are fatal ones
column46: the basic game mechanics are very solid
column47: although in some ways the level design of The New Order was superior
column48: this is still one of the best shooters to come out in recent years. The basic gameplay is the same style as TNO
column49: combat is very satisfying. It doesn't really try to do a hole lot more than The New Order
column52: what TNO did was show how to make a good singleplayer FPS in this era
column53: and The Old Blood delivers a lite version of that
column54: for half the price.\nWolfenstein: The Old Blood
column56: I'd hesitate to call it a great game
column57: but I'd hesitate even more to hold that against it because it's not trying to be anything more than what it is
column58: and what it is is satisfying enough for me."

reviewText:
Mostly AWESOME!
While probably not as original and fresh in terms of concept as The New order, The Old Blood makes a lot of things much better than it's predecessor and mostly in game design itself....shooting mechanics are as awesome as before, however this game gives much more satisfaction since it is not felt ABRUPT wich was the greatest issue of TNO. Most of levels are long, there's lots of secret places to find and those not only containing some treasure or ammo but also some interesting info. Pacing is great......chapter 4 is the greatest segment in the game, it is almost perfect! The later part of TOB is  somewhat different since it throws you back to ocult and supernatural stuff it's a little bit repetetive and not really that well thought, but nether the less it brings enough fun to keep you enjoying the process. this part reminded me a little bit of NecroVision wich is just simply ♥♥♥♥ing awesome shooter.
Level design is excellent, visuals are fantastic.
SO it is a MUST HAVE for any true FPS fan and of course a Wolf fan, with never ending gameplay and without  unnecesary story telling!))

Definitely buy this game but only if you are absolutely certain your machine can run it properly.

reviewText:
Excellent game: feels like a cross between RtCW and TNO in theme, and plays as well as TNO. Less cinematics and cutscenes than TNO, and relies more on readable papers and letter from the environment to convey detail beyond what the playthrough will illuminate. Lots of secret places to find as well, some of which also contain more background info.

The gunplay is still great and the new weapons fit in just fine. My playthrough took me about 10 hours at a leisurly pace. I feel it was money well spent.

Double check to see if your hardware setup will work with this or other ID Engine 5 games.

reviewText:
Highly recommended. This game is what I wanted New Order to be. It keeps in line with the retro futuristic weird WW2 vibe more so than New Order. It has the feel of an old school shooter; secret rooms not on maps, hidden treasures, and labyrinthine maps with multiple ways to approach a situation. The stealth mechanic is great as well. It's not all run and gun. Lastly, the storytelling is great. Collectible notes and easter eggs as opposed to horrible cutscenes.

Overall if you're a fan of the Wolfenstein series but have been bummed since Return to Castle Wolfenstein, this is the game for you.

10/10 Get ready to collect Nazi gold like a crazed Mossad agent.

reviewText:
When I was a kid, playing Wolfenstein 3D in 1993, I found the game scary. The nazis were overwhelming and the mazes were just soaked with nazi decadence I was so used to seeing growing up in the post-war central Europe, where it's all still a relatively fresh memory.

I am so glad this game exists. Though this is an expansion pack technically to the already excellent Wolfenstein: The New Order, it is also a worthy reimagining of the Wolfenstein 3D saga. Its story fits the plot well. I remember when I first saw the original loading screen for Wolf 3D, where Blazkowitz hides behind a wall and the soldier approaches, it reminded me of Raiders of the Lost Ark, when Indy actually briefly dresses up as a german to infiltrate the submarine docking station in Act 3. That always made me think of Wolfenstein and I dreamt of a Spielbergian Wolfenstein film with Harrison Ford as Blazsko.

But along came this game instead, with all its subtle naunces and historically accurate(ish) feeling design.
It delivers on some primal aspect that made the original Wolf 3D (1993) work. Just the fact that you can always pick up food is such a satisfying improvement. And the subtle references that you can catch, you can geek out about them for hours. The elongated skulls, displayed along a wall, natural curiosities...subtle references to the past and other related titles, the excellent writing and subtle plot... Yes, this game is obviously fictitious, but it grasps quite well what Nazis were and are, not just as antagonists but historical figures and puts it into probably the most enjoyable FPS I've played in a decade. This game, this specific stand-alone 'expansion', is one of those games you'll remember, like Wolf 3D or Duke Nukem, because it follows principles of good design throughout. And that's TREMENDOUS these days.

Though killing nazis in a dystopian alternative history future is a bleak feat, and the authenticity of the filth and horrible energy Nazis had is conveyed not just through environments and interactions but even music in such a masterful way it leaves a lasting impression. But don't worry, there are bits where Blazsko is the anti-hero everyone wants him to be and even bits where he could be rubbing shoulders with John McClaine we wanted to be in all the Die Hard movies, not just the first. Whoever wrote for this game and held it together, hats off sir (or madam), and Thank You to the whole team and highest commendations, there is so much greatness in this game it's impossible to compress into a short review.

Buy this, you really won't regret it. At $20, it's like we're back in 1993 and you're borrowing your friend's floppy disks with Wolf 3D scribbled on with sharpies. Go on, have a great time.

reviewText:
I bought this game without knowing much about it.
I know the wolfenstein franchise (who doesn't) since wolfenstein 3D so I was quite sure it would be above average.
And it is.
Technicaly it is flawless.
The gameplay is also very nice. I liked the pipe as a weapon/tool, it's a simple and elegant idea, quite nicely introduced to the game.
Nice array of weapons to choose from too.
The fact that you can try to go stealth, or berzerk, killing everything gives a nice variety to the gameplay.
The story stands up and is well constructed without any new ideas though.
The levels are big and with an astonishing amount of detail. A real feast to the eyes.
Until ... the zombies. Come on! Aren't there enough zombie games?
I mean, the game is still a solid game, and would be with or without zombies, so I thnk they should have tried to find other ways to fill in the story paranormal" side.
But I still recommend it without a doubt. Good value for money
date: although it could be a little longer.\nA must try."

reviewText:
A nice standalone prequel to The New Order. However, there are only sparse links between the two, so no spoilers or need to play both in any sort of order.

Coming from the New Order, it's generally more of the same. And that's a good thing. Good shooting, decent story/pacing. Overall, without exploring every nook and cranny for collectibles that I don't care about, it took me around 10 hours to finish. And it feels about right.

If I had some criticisms:
1) The Graveyard could have been longer.
2) Some of the later levels felt very small/clausterphobic when they didn't need to be.
3) A lot of the NPCs don't stick around very long. In The New Order, you were with the same crew" most of the game and it helped develop a relationship with the characters. In The Old Blood
date: they just come and go and you never get much time with them.\n4) A lot of the levels felt as if you HAD to sneak around in them. I understand that you don't
recommended: but it would be extremely punishing otherwise.\n5) The diffculty ramped up HARD after Chapter 3/4. Up until then
hoursPlayed: on "Bring 'Em On" difficulty I was thinking I had chosen too low. Then it just got crazy.\n\nWould definitely recommend as a solid first person shooter."
